#### For example:

### χωρᾳ, _land_

Listen

## Iota Subscript

When the long vowels α,η,ω meet a short ι, the ι is written under (subscript!)
these letters instead of being written next to them. A **iota subscript** is
never pronounced.

So,

  * α \+ ι = ᾳ
  * η \+ ι = ῃ
  * ω \+ ι = ῳ

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## Third Accent Rule: Grave Accent

  1. **The grave accent appears _only_ on the ultima.**
  2. The acute accent turns into a grave accent on the ultima **when the word is not followed by a punctuation mark, but by another word**. 

* * *

## πολλὰ κακά meaning "many evil (things)"

πολλ_ά_

* * *  
  
---  
Changes its accent when not followed by a punctuation mark, like so:  
πολλ_ὰ_ κακά.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## Second Accent Rule: Acute Accent

  1. The acute accent, like other accents, can _never_ must be placed one one of the last three syllables of a word. 
  2. It can be found over the antepenult _only_ if the last syllable is short.

* * *

Names for the Syllables in a Greek Word

## ἄνθρωπος meaning "Man"

* * *

_ἄ_ν

* * *

|  θρω

* * *

|  πος

* * *  
  
---|---|---  
**Antepenult**  
|  **Penult**  
|  **Ultima**  
  
  
This example shows how the **acute accent** of this word is placed on the
antepenult (ἄν) **because the ultima** (πος) **is short**.

For the Ultima to be long, it would need to contain a long vowel, such as ω.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
#### Accent Names

* * *

## **´** Acute

## **`** Grave

## **῀** Circumflex

## Accents

In the Greek language, accents are very important and should be learned as an
intergral part of its spelling. Accents determine the music of a word and
indicate which vowels in the word should be emphasized. When pronouncing a
Greek word, simply _stress the vowel_ on which you see an accent! Take a look
at the table to learn what the **three Greek accents** are.

* * *

To help you with the spelling of Greek words, you should know that **the
accents follow four very specific sets of rules**.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## Fourth Accent Rule: Circumflex Accent

  1. The circumflex accent can _only_ be placed **on the penult or ultima**.
  2. The circumflex accent can _only_ be placed **on long vowels or dipthongs** (You will learn about dipthongs shortly).

* * *

For example:

## σῶμα meaning "Body"

* * *

σ_ῶ_

* * *

|  μα

* * *  
  
---|---  
**Penult**  
|  **Ultima**  
  
  
The **circumflex accent** is placed on the **penult**. The penult is a **long
syllable** because it contains the long vowel, ῶ, omega.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
##### Long and Short Vowels

Long | Long or Short | Short  
---|---|---  
α | α | α  
η |  | ε  
ι | ι | ι  
ω |  | ο  
υ | υ | υ  
  
## Long and Short Vowels

The Ancient Greeks pronounced vowels differently according to their "length".
The length of a vowel, therefore, has an effect on the accent rules that you
will be learning later in this unit. For now, all that you need to know is
that vowels can be divided into two categories:

  * **Long vowels**
  * **Short vowels**

Some vowels can be both long or short depending on the word. Take a look at
the table to learn which ones.

Notice how η is simply the long version of ε, and ω is the long version of ο.

### ὀλιγαρχία, _oligarchy_

Listen

## Smooth Breathing

When words begin with a _vowel_, but don't have a rough breathing, then you
will see this sign ᾿ on the first letter. This sign ᾿ is called **smooth
breathing**. Smooth breathings have no effect on pronunciation.

* * *

#####  Useful tip!

The majority of words beginning with a vowel will have a **smooth breathing**.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
![](/static/images/new_thuc.png) ![](/static/images/glasses.svg)

> _I should really write "The Dipthong Song"._ Thucydides

## Greek Diacritics and Dipthongs  
Learn the diacritics and dipthongs to read and write as the Greeks did!

* * *

Now that you have learned the Greek alphabet, it's time for you to become
familiar with the Greek diacritics and dipthongs.

* * *

**Diacritics** are signs or marks attached to a letter that distinguish it from another of similar form, giving it a different phonetic value. Diacritics give Ancient Greek its own music! 

* * *

**Dipthongs** indicate two vowels that, when next to each other, are pronounced as one. 

* * *

### You're going to learn

   5 New Skills           10 New Words           No history

  1. Rough and smooth breathings.
  2. Long and short vowels.
  3. Iota subscript.
  4. Accents.
  5. Dipthongs.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
#### For example:

* * *

### ὁδός, _way_

Listen

* * *

#### Or:

### ῾´Ελληνες, _Greeks_

Listen

## Rough Breathing

When you see this sign ῾ on the first letter of a word beginning with a
_vowel_, you are looking at a **rough breathing**. The Greeks used it to
indicate that the word would be pronounced as though the first letter were
preceded by an "H".

* * *

#####  Useful tip!

**All words** starting with the vowel **υ** have a rough breathing. **All words** starting with **ρ** also have a rough breathing, but in this case, as ρ is a consonant and not a vowel, the breathing has no effect on how the word sounds.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## First Accent Rule: General

**Accents can _only_ appear over one of the last three _syllables_ of a word**, no matter how many syllables a word has. Each of the last three syllables has its own name, so that it is easier to define the position of an accent. 

* * *

Names for the Syllables in a Greek Word

## ἄνθρωπος meaning "Man"

* * *

ἄν

* * *

|  θρω

* * *

|  πος

* * *  
  
---|---|---  
**Antepenult**  

* * *

Third syllable from the end.  
"Ante" meaning "before", "penult" meaning "second to last".  |  **Penult**  

* * *

Second to last  
or "penultimate" syllable.  |  **Ultima**  

* * *

Last syllable  
Like "Ultimate", meaning "last".  
  
![](/static/images/new_thuc.png) ![](/static/images/glasses.svg)

This example shows how the **acute accent** of this word is placed on the
vowel in the **antepenult** syllable.

* * *

### Listen up!

Just like vowels, syllables can also be defined as _long or short_ depending
on which vowel/s form them. So, for example, **a syllable containing a long α
will be a long syllable.**

You'll use this knowledge for moving accents around!

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
##### Dipthongs

αι |  Listen  
---|---  
ει |  Listen  
οι |  Listen  
υι |  Listen  
αυ |  Listen  
ευ |  Listen  
ηυ |  Listen  
ου |  Listen  
  
## Dipthongs

**Dipthongs are vowels in pairs of two that produce one long sound**. Words that begin with a dipthong will have either a rough or smooth breathing (depending on the word). Whichever breathing it is, it is placed on the second vowel of the dipthong. For example: αἰτία, _cause_. 

All dipthongs are counted as **long**.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
##### Three-ending Adjectives of the First and Second Declension,
δίκαιος,δικαία,δίκαιον _righteous_

| Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | δίκαιος | δικαία | δίκαιον  
Gen. | δικαίου | δικαίας | δικαίου  
Dat. | δικαίῳ | δικαίᾳ | δικαίῳ | Acc. | δίκαιον | δικαίαν | δίκαιον | Voc. |
δίκαιε | δικαία | δίκαιον | **Plural**  
Nom. | δίκαιοι | δίκαιαι | δίκαια  
Gen. | δικαίων | δικαίων | δικαίων  
Dat. | δικαίοις | δικαίαις | δικαίοις  
Acc. | δικαίους | δικαίας | δίκαια  
Voc. | δίκαιοι | δίκαιαι | δίκαια  
  
#### How Greek Verbs work

Just like nouns, Greek verbs are inflected and just like nouns they add an
ending to their stem to produce their various forms. While the patterns for
nouns are called declensions (and the noun is declined), the verb forms fall
into **conjugations** (so the verb is **conjugated**).  
Most Greek verbs will have these 5 important characteristics:

  1. **Person**
  2. **Number**
  3. **Tense**
  4. **Mood**
  5. **Voice**

* * *

##### Useful tip!

Unlike English verbs, the subject of the Greek verb is implied by the verb's
ending. Therefore, it is not necessary for it to be accompanied by the
personal pronouns _I, You, He/She/It, We, You, They_.  
For example: The English _I have_ can be translated either ἐγώ ἔχω or, more
commonly, simply  ἔχω.

Soon you will be able to identify the **5 characteristics of Greek verbs**
yourself! Click onthe arrow to find out how.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
#### Adverbs

Most adjectives in Ancient Greek are formed by adding -**ως** to the stem.
Remember the stem is found by dropping the ending of the masculine genitive
singular! The following are a few examples of the process of deriving an
adverb from an adjective.

Nominative Masculine Singular | Genitive Masculine Singular | Adverb  
---|---|---  
δίκαιος (just) | **δικαί**ου | **δικαίως** (justly)  
ἄδικος (unjust) | **ἀδίκ**ου | **ἀδίκως** (unjustly)  
πᾶς (whole) | **παντ**ός | **πάντως** (wholly)  
ἡδύς (sweet) | **ἡδέ**ος | **ἡδέως** (sweetly)

# Adjectives: Third Declension

* * *

Now is a good time to learn everything about **Greek Adverbs**!

* * *

## In this Section

New Skills New Vocab The Athenians conquer Sicyon, but lose in Thessaly and
Acarnia.

  1. Identify adverbs.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
###

![](/static/images/map.jpg)

The Athenians win Sicyon and lose Acarnia.

## ...previously in the Pentecontaetia

The Athenians were forced to leave Egypt after six years of war.

## Now in the Pentecontaetia...

Orestes, son of the Thessalian king, wants to be restored as master of
Thessaly. To this end, he persuades the Athenians to march on Thessaly and
bend the inhabitants to their will. However, the Athenians fail and Orestes is
not restored!

Under the command of Pericles, the Athenians now land on Sicyon and conquer
it. They fail, however, to win over Acarnia.

(Summary of Thuc. 1.111)

Now that you've got some context, let's look at adverbs!  
  
**Click the arrow to start learning!**

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
#### Adverbs

There is another kind of adverb formed by the **accusative neuter (singular or
plural) of adjectives**. Take a look at some examples below.

Adjective | Adverb  
---|---  
ὀξύς (acute) | **ὀξύ** (acutely)  
πολύς (much) | **πολύ/πολλά** (much)  
μέγας (big) | **μέγα/μεγάλα** (largely)  
  
Don't leave yet! There is one last type of adverb formed with the **accusative
and dative of feminine adjectives or nouns**. Take a look at some examples
below.

Noun/Adjective | Adverb  
---|---  
ἡ χάρις (the grace) | **χάριν** (thanks to)  
τὸ τέλος (the end) | **τέλος** (finally)  
ἡ ἀρχή (the beginning) | **ἀρχήν** (initially)  
ἴδιος (private) | **ἰδίᾳ** (privately)  
δημόσιος (public) | **δεμοσίᾳ** (publicly)  
πεζός (walking) | **πεζῇ** (on foot)

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
#### Adverbs

Another kind of adverb ends in -**ω**. These derive from prepositions. Take a
look at some examples below.

Preposition | Adverb  
---|---  
ἀνά (up) | **ἄνω** (on top)  
κατά (down) | **κάτω** (underneath)  
εἰς (towards) | **εἴσω** (inside)  
ἐκ/ἐξ (from) | **ἔξω** (outside)

> _I'll also answer to Mr. T. Just sayin'._ Thucydides _(ca 460 - 395 BC)_

# Let's get started, shall we?

**Welcome aboard, aspiring Geek!**

  

The name is Thucydides. I'll be your guide through the Ancient Greek language
and beyond. You'll learn more about me in a few lessons, but for now let's
dive into the alphabet. Let me tell you something:

  

**I pity the fool, who doesn't know the Greek alphabet**.

So click the page corner to get your Greek on!  

* * *

### You're going to learn

New Skills New Vocab History

  1. Identify and pronounce upper and lowercase Greek letters.
  2. Understand Greek punctuation

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## Greek Punctuation

In Greek printed texts, the comma (**,**) and the period (**.**) have the same
use as in English.

The semicolon (**;**) is used in Greek as a question mark (?).

The raised period (**·**) is equivalent to both the English semicolon (;) and
colon (:).

, . ; ·

In Greek

, . ? ;/:

In English

fields.title: UPDATE ME!

## A few things to remember!

The following **letter combinations** might at first appear hard to pronounce.

Take a look at the following table to find out how to tackle them easily:

## Digraphs in Greek

These so-called "γ nasals" are example of _digraphs_ in Ancient Greek. _Di_,
meaning 'two', and _graph_ meaning 'something written'.

Letter combination | Pronunciation | Example | Pronunciation  
---|---|---|---  
γγ | ng | ἄγγελος | angelos  
γκ | nk | ἄγκυρα | anküra  
γχ | nkh | λόγχη | lonkhe  
γξ | nx | σάλπιγξ | salpinx  
  
You don't need to know what they're called, just remember that if a γ is
followed by another γ, or a κ, χ, ξ, you should pronounce the first γ as
though it were actually a ν.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## The Greek Alphabet

The Greek alphabet comprises **24 letters** (7 vowels and 17 consonants). The
alphabet you will learn is the Ionic alphabet first adopted in Athens at the
end of the 5th century BC.

### The Greek Alphabet

Uppercase | Lowercase | Name | Pronunciation  
---|---|---|---  
Α | α | alpha | a  
Β | β | beta | b  
Γ | γ | gamma | g (like "glue")  
Δ | δ | delta | d  
Ε | ε | epsilon | e (like "get")  
Z | ζ | zdeta | zd  
Η | η | eta | e (like "hair")  
Θ | θ | theta | th  
Ι | ι | iota | i (like "east")  
Κ | κ | kappa | k  
Λ | λ | lambda | l  
Μ | μ | mü | m  
Ν | ν | nü | n  
Ξ | ξ | ksi | x  
Ο | ο | omicron | o  
Π | π | pi | p  
Ρ | ρ | rho | r  
Σ | σ or ς* | sigma | s  
Τ | τ | tau | t  
Υ | υ | üpsilon | ü  
Φ | φ | fi | f  
Χ | χ | khi | kh  
Ψ | ψ | psi | ps  
Ω | ω | omega | o  
  
* σ is used when the letter is in the middle of the word. ς is used when the letter is at the end of the word.

#### First Declension: 3 groups

Case | I. | II. | III.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | -α | -η | -ης  
Gen. | -ας | -ης | -ου  
Dat. | -ᾳ | -ῃ | -ῃ  
Acc. | -αν | -ην | -ην  
Voc. | -α | -η | -α  
**Plural**  
Nom. | -αι | -αι | -αι  
Gen. | -ῶν | -ῶν | -ῶν  
Dat. | -αις | -αις | -αις  
Acc. | -ας | -ας | -ας  
Voc. | -αι | -αι | -αι  
  
Notice again that all the plural forms are identical.

## The First Declension in the Pentecontaetia

Take a look at another two examples showing first declension nouns in the
Pentecontaetia.

[...] **οἰκίαι αἱ** μὲν πολλαὶ |  ἐπεπτώκεσαν  
---|---  
[...] many **houses** |  had fallen  
**(Nominative)** |  (Verb)   
-- _The History of the Peloponnesian War_, 1.89.3

Keep Reading »

Λακεδαιμόνιοι δὲ αἰσθόμενοι |  [...] ἦλθον |  **πρεσβείᾳ**  
---|---|---  
Perceiving this, the Spartans  |  went  |  with **an embassy** [...]  
(Nominative)  |  (Verb)  |  **(Dative)**  
-- _The History of the Peloponnesian War_, 1.91.1

> _Decline first, ask questions later._ Thucydides _(ca 460 - 395 BC)_

# First Declension

* * *

Now that you have learned how to identify the 3 main characteristics of Greek
nouns, how to distinguish the 5 Greek cases and understand the role that cases
individually play in a sentence, **you are ready for your first declension**!

* * *

## In this Section

New Skills New Vocab History

  1. Identify first declension nouns ending in -α.
  2. Identify first declension nouns ending in -η.
  3. Identify first declension nouns ending in -ης.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### Themistocles

  
(524–459 BC) was a powerful Athenian politician and general.

![](/static/images/them.png)

I am most famous for participating in the Battle of Marathon and the Battle of
Salamis.

## The very beginning of the Pentecontaetia.

The Pentecontaetia starts when οἱ Ἕλληνες, the Hellenes, finally defeat the
Persians at Mycale.

As the conflict ends, both the Persians and the Hellenes gradually make their
way home. Upon their return, οἱ Ἀθηναῖοι, the Athenians, decide to rebuild
their αἱ οἰκίαι, their homes, and especially their τό τεῖχος, their wall.

However, when οἱ Λακεδαιμόνιοι, the Spartans, hear of this, they attempt to
dissuade the Athenians from building a wall, for they fear the strength of
Athens and the power of its newly acquired navy. Themistocles, an influential
Athenian politician and general, refuses to stop the works on the wall and
orders that all οἱ πολῖται, all citizens, including women and children, help
rebuild it. He himself leaves immediately for Sparta in an attempt to cover up
the rebuilding of the wall, knowing the Spartans would not be pleased if they
found out the truth!

(Summary of [Thuc. 1.89-90](/reader/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0003.tlg001.perseus-
grc1:1.89.0))

Now that you've got some context, let's look at first declension nouns.  
**Click the arrow to start learning!**

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
##### ἡ χώρα,ας: The land, of the land

Case | Article, Noun  
---|---  
**Singular** | **Plural**  
Nom. | ἡ χώρ**α** | αἱ χῶρ**αι**  
Gen. | τῆς χώρ**ας** | τῶν χωρ**ῶν**  
Dat. | τῇ χωρ**ᾳ** | ταῖς χῶρ**αις**  
Acc. | τὴν χώρ**αν** | τὰς χώρ**ας**  
Voc. | ὦ χώρ**α** | ὦ χῶρ**αι**  
  
## First declension

The first Greek declension consists of **nearly exclusively feminine nouns**.
Only few masculine nouns belong to the first declension and no neuter nouns.

The first and most common group of nouns ends in -α in the whole singular and
plural. Take a look at the declension of ἡ χώρα meaning _the land_.

* * *

####  Look out for Accents!

When a first declension noun has an acute accent on the last syllable in the
nominative, the accent is changed to a circumflex in the genitive and dative,
in both the singular and plural.

For example: ἡ στρατιά (meaning _the army_) will become τῆς στρατιᾶς in the
genitive singular.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## What is a declension?

A declension is a group of nouns, pronouns, adjectives, and articles that
follow a particular **pattern of inflection**. There are 3 declensions in
Greek. Each noun belongs to only one declension and can only have the endings
that belong to that particular declension. Those nouns whose endings are (for
the most part) the vowels -α or -η, belong to the **first declension**. Those
nouns ending in -ο belong to the **second declension**. All the other nouns
belong to the **third declension**.

####  Reading a Dictionary Entry

The vocabulary entry for each noun shows the nominative and the genitive
forms, the definite article and the English meaning. For example:

χώρα, ας ἡ...land, country

To decline any noun, take the **genitive singular**, remove the ending to get
the stem, and then add the right set of endings to the stem.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## First declension continued...

The third group of nouns end in -ης in the singular and in -α in the plural.
These strictly masculine nouns take, of course, masculine definite articles,
their genitive singular ends in -ου and their vocative singular in -α.

Take a look at the declension of ὁ πολίτης meaning _the citizen_.

##### ὁ πολίτης,ου: the citizen

**Singular** | **Plural**  
---|---  
Nom. | ὁ πολίτ**ης** | οἱ πολῖτ**αι**  
Gen. | τοῦ πολίτ**ου** | τῶν πολιτ**ῶν**  
Dat. | τῶ πολίτ**ῃ** | τοῖς πολίτ**αις**  
Acc. | τὸν πολίτ**ην** | τοὺς πολίτ**ας**  
Voc. | ὦ πολῖτ**α** | ὦ πολῖτ**αι**

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### First Declension: 3 groups

Case | I. | II. | III.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | -α | -η | -ης  
Gen. | -ας | -ης | -ου  
Dat. | -ᾳ | -ῃ | -ῃ  
Acc. | -αν | -ην | -ην  
Voc. | -α | -η | -α  
**Plural**  
Nom. | -αι | -αι | -αι  
Gen. | -ῶν | -ῶν | -ῶν  
Dat. | -αις | -αις | -αις  
Acc. | -ας | -ας | -ας  
Voc. | -αι | -αι | -αι  
  
Notice again that all the plural forms are identical.

## The First Declension in the Pentecontaetia

The following is an example of how Thucydides himself makes use of first
declension nouns in the Pentecontaetia.

[...] οἱ βάρβαροι |  ἐκ**τῆς χώρας** |  ἀπῆλθον  
---|---|---  
[...] the barbarians  |  from the country  |  departed  
(Nominative)  |  (Genitive)  |  (Verb)  
-- _The History of the Peloponnesian War_, 1.89.3

Keep Reading »

![](/static/images/thuc.png)

τῆς χώρας belongs to the first group of first declension nouns. It is
feminine, singular and in the genitive case!

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
##### Three-ending Adjectives of the First and Second Declension,
δίκαιος,δικαία,δίκαιον _righteous_

| Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | δίκαιος | δικαία | δίκαιον  
Gen. | δικαίου | δικαίας | δικαίου  
Dat. | δικαίῳ | δικαίᾳ | δικαίῳ | Acc. | δίκαιον | δικαίαν | δίκαιον | Voc. |
δίκαιε | δικαία | δίκαιον | **Plural**  
Nom. | δίκαιοι | δίκαιαι | δίκαια  
Gen. | δικαίων | δικαίων | δικαίων  
Dat. | δικαίοις | δικαίαις | δικαίοις  
Acc. | δικαίους | δικαίας | δίκαια  
Voc. | δίκαιοι | δίκαιαι | δίκαια  
  
#### How Greek Verbs work

Just like nouns, Greek verbs are inflected and just like nouns they add an
ending to their stem to produce their various forms. While the patterns for
nouns are called declensions (and the noun is declined), the verb forms fall
into **conjugations** (so the verb is **conjugated**).  
Most Greek verbs will have these 5 important characteristics:

  1. **Person**
  2. **Number**
  3. **Tense**
  4. **Mood**
  5. **Voice**

* * *

##### Useful tip!

Unlike English verbs, the subject of the Greek verb is implied by the verb's
ending. Therefore, it is not necessary for it to be accompanied by the
personal pronouns _I, You, He/She/It, We, You, They_.  
For example: The English _I have_ can be translated either ἐγώ ἔχω or, more
commonly, simply  ἔχω.

Soon you will be able to identify the **5 characteristics of Greek verbs**
yourself! Click onthe arrow to find out how.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## How First and Second Declension Adjectives work

Just like articles and nouns have gender, number and case, so do all the
adjectives. Like the article, **an adjective must agree in gender, number and
case with the noun it describes**.

However, this does not mean that the ending of the article and that of the
noun are always identical; there are exceptions where, though the adjective
and noun agree, the endings might look different.

Adjectives agreeing with third declension nouns fall into two groups:

  * **Three-ending Adjectives**  
These can have three types of endings:

    * -**ας** -**ασα**
-**αν**
    * -**ας** -**αινα**
-**αν**
    * -**ύς** -**εῖα**
-**ύ**
  
  
  
  

  * **Two-ending Adjectives**  
These can have two types of endings:

    * -**ων** for masculine and feminine; -**ον**
for neuter

    * -**ης** for masculine and feminine; -**ες**
for neuter  
  

* * *

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
![](/static/images/new_thuc.png) ![](/static/images/glasses.svg)

> _The OBjective is to learn the ADjective!_ Thucydides _(ca 460 - 395 BC)_

# Adjectives: Third Declension

* * *

Now is a good time to learn everything about **Third Declension Adjectives**!

* * *

## In this Section

New Skills New Vocab The Athenian defeat in Egypt.

  1. Identify and decline three-ending adjectives.
  2. Identify and decline two-ending adjectives.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### εὐδαίμων, εὔδαιμον -- _happy_

Two-ending Adjective

| Masc./Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | εὐδαίμων | εὔδαιμον  
Gen. | εὐδαίμον**ος** | εὐδαίμον**ος**  
Dat. | εὐδαίμον**ι** | εὐδαίμον**ι** | Acc. | εὐδαίμον**α** | εὔδαιμον | Voc.
| εὔδαιμον | εὔδαιμον | **Plural**  
Nom. | εὐδαίμον**ες** | εὐδαίμον**α**  
Gen. | εὐδαιμόν**ων** | εὐδαιμόν**ων**  
Dat. | εὐδαίμο**σι(ν)** | εὐδαίμο**σι(ν)**  
Acc. | εὐδαίμον**ας** | εὐδαίμον**α**  
Voc. | εὐδαίμον**ες** | εὐδαίμον**α**  
  
## Two-ending Adjectives of the Third Declension

The adjectives of the third declension with two endings are declined just like
the third declension nouns with consonant stems. These adjectives have one
type of ending for masculine and feminine, and one type for neuter.

Look at the following example of εὐδαίμ**ων**, εὔδαιμ**ον**, meaning _happy_.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### Egypt

![](/static/images/egypt.jpg)

The Athenians leave Egypt after six years of war.

## ...previously in the Pentecontaetia

The Athenians defeat the Boeotians and become their masters.

## Now in the Pentecontaetia...

The Persians defeat the Egyptians and their allies from Athens. So, after six
years of war, the Athenians are defeated.

Egypt returns to the subjection of its king. Later, Inaros, king of the
Libyans on the Egyption border, is betrayed and crucified.

(Summary of Thuc. 1.109-110)

Now that you've got some context, let's look at the adjectives of the third
declension!  
  
**Click the arrow to start learning!**

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### εὐγενής, εὐγενές -- _noble_

Two-ending Adjective

| Masc./Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | εὐγενής | εὐγενές  
Gen. | εὐγεν**οῦς** | εὐγεν**οῦς**  
Dat. | εὐγενε**ῖ** | εὐγενε**ῖ** | Acc. | εὐγενῆ** | εὐγενές | Voc. | εὐγενές
| εὐγενές | **Plural**  
Nom. | εὐγενεῖς | εὐγενῆ  
Gen. | εὐγεν**ῶν** | εὐγεν**ῶν**  
Dat. | εὐγενέ**σι(ν)** | εὐγενέ**σι(ν)**  
Acc. | εὐγενεῖς | εὐγενῆ  
Voc. | εὐγενεῖς | εὐγενῆ  
  
## Two-ending Adjectives of the Third Declension

And now another example with different endings: εὐγεν**ής**, εὐγεν**ές**,
meaning _noble_.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### πᾶς, πᾶσα, πᾶν -- _every_

Three-ending Adjective

| Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | πᾶς | πᾶσ**α** | πᾶν  
Gen. | παντ**ός** | πάσ**ης** | παντ**ός**  
Dat. | παντ**ί** | πάσ**ῃ** | παντ**ί** | Acc. | πάντ**α** | πᾶσ**αν** | πᾶν |
Voc. | πᾶς | πᾶσ**α** | πᾶν | **Plural**  
Nom. | πάντ**ες** | πᾶσ**αι** | πάντ**α**  
Gen. | πάντ**ων** | πασ**ῶν** | πάντ**ων**  
Dat. | πᾶ**σι(ν)** | πάσ**αις** | πᾶ**σι(ν)**  
Acc. | πάντ**ας** | πάσ**ας** | πάντ**α**  
Voc. | πάντ**ες** | πᾶσ**αι** | πάντ**α**  
  
## Three-ending Adjectives of the First and Second Declension

As you can see from the table, the adjective πᾶς, πᾶσα, πᾶν has forms of the
first and third declensions.

##### Useful tip

The adjective πᾶς, πᾶσα, πᾶν often also means _all_ or _whole_.

* * *

Another adjective that follows this pattern is μέλ**ας**, μέλ**αινα**,
μέλ**αν**, meaning _black_. If you look closely the endings for this
particular adjective, though similar, are somewhat different from those in
πᾶς, πᾶσα, πᾶν.

* * *

The very last type of adjectives following this pattern is ἡδ**ύς**,
ἡδ**εῖα**, ἡδ**ύ**, meaning _sweet_.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
#### τό ἔργον,ου: The body, of the body

**Singular** | **Plural**  
---|---  
Nom. | τό σῶμα | τά σώματ**α**  
Gen. | τοῦ σῶματ**ος** | τῶν σωμάτ**ων**  
Dat. | τῷ σώματ**ι** | τοῖς σώμα**σι(ν)**  
Acc. | τό σῶμα | τά σῶμα**τα**  
Voc. | ῷ σῶμα | ῷ σῶμα**τα**  
  
## Third declension continued...

And now here is an example of a neuter third declension noun: τό σῶμα meaning
_the body_.

* * *

### Neuter Nouns are a Special Case

In all neuter nouns, **the accusative and the vocative are the same as the
nominative**. This works for both singular and plural.

# Third Declension Nouns: Consonant Stem

* * *

Now is a good time to introduce you to **third declension nouns**!

* * *

## In this Section

New Skills New Vocab News from the Oracle of Delphi

  1. Identify third declension nouns with consonant stems.
  2. Identify dative plural ending exceptions.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## A few things to remember!

When the final consonant of a stem meets the **dative plural** ending -σι , it
causes the following spelling and phonetic changes:

The consonants are grouped according to sound.

Type of consonant | Consonants |  | Dative Ending |  | Results in | Example  
---|---|---|---|---|---|---  
Labial | π, β, φ | + | -σι | = | **-ψι** | φλεβ+σί = φλεψί  
Velar | κ, γ, χ | + | -σι | = | **-ξι** | φύλακ+σι = φύλαξι  
Dental | τ, δ, θ | + | -σι | = | **-σι** | ἐλπίδ+σι = ἐλπίσι  
Stem in -ντ | -αντ | + | -σι | = | **-ασι** | γίγαντ+σι = γίγασι  
Stem in -ντ | -οντ | + | -σι | = | **-ουσι** | γέροντ+σι = γέρουσι

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### The Oracle of Delphi

![](/static/images/oracle.jpg)

The Oracle, situated in the sanctuary of Delphi, was home to a frenzied
priestess, believed to utter the words of the gods and predict future events.

## ...previously in the Pentecontaetia

The Athenians renounced the alliance with Sparta.

## Now in the Pentecontaetia...

The Helots finally surrender to Sparta on condition that they leave ἡ
Πελοπόννησος, the Peloponnesus, and never return. The Spartans have, in fact,
received an oracle from Delphi instructing exactly this. The Helots are
received by the Athenians, who place them at Naupactus. A dispute with Corinth
leads ἡ Μεγάρη, Megara, to ally herself with Athens.

Meanwhile, ὁ βασιλεὺς, the king of the Libyans on the Egyptian border, Inaros,
causes a revolt of almost the whole of Egypt against the Persians. He invites
the Athenians to assist him. The Athenians immediately sail to Egypt and enter
through the Nile. They quickly establish themselves themselves as masters of
the river.

(Summary of Thuc. 1.103-104)

Now that you've got some context, let's look at third declension nouns!  
  
**Click the arrow to start learning!**

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
##### Third Declension: Consonant Stem

Case | Singular | Plural  
---|---|---  
**Feminine/Masculine**  
Nom. | - | -ες  
Gen. | -ος | -ων  
Dat. | -ι | -σι(ν)  
Acc. | -α, -ν | -ας  
Voc. | - | -οι  
**Neuter**  
Nom. | - | -α  
Gen. | -ος | -ων  
Dat. | -ι | -σι(ν)  
Acc. | - | -α  
Voc. | - | -α  
  
#### The Third Declension in the Pentecontaetia

The following is an example of how Thucydides himself makes use of third
declension nouns in the Pentecontaetia.

οἰ [...] Ἀθηναῖοι |  τρόπῳ τοιῷδε |  ἧλθον |  ἐπὶ τὰ πράγματα**  
---|---|---|---  
The [...] Athenians  |  in this way  |  came  |  **to the circumstances...**  
(Nominative)  |  **   |  (Verb)  |  
-- _The History of the Peloponnesian War_, 1.89.1

Keep Reading »

![](/static/images/thuc.png)

τὰ πράγματα is a neuter, accusative plural of the noun τό πρᾶγμα.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
##### ἡ ἐλπίς,ἐλπίδος: The hope, of the hope

**Singular** | **Plural**  
---|---  
Nom. | ἡ ἐλπίς | αἱ ἐλπίδ**ες**  
Gen. | τῆς ἐλπίδ**ος** | τῶν ἐλπίδ**ων**  
Dat. | τῇ ἐλπίδ**ι** | ταῖς ἐλπί**σἱ(ν)**  
Acc. | τὴν ἐλπίδ**α** | τὰς ἐλπίδ**ας**  
Voc. | ὦ ἐλπί | ὦ ἐλπίδ**ες**  
  
## Third declension: consonant stem

Third declension nouns can be masculine, feminine, or neuter. They are called
"nouns with consonant stems" because their stems end with a consonant and so
that they distinguish themselves from third declension nouns with vowel stems.

* * *

Unlike nouns from the first and second declensions, **the nominative singular
forms of third declension nouns don't have a specific ending** \- rather, the
ending of every noun is different. However, some features of the third
declension remain stable for every noun. These are:

  * the endings of the genitive
  * the endings of the dative
  * the endings of the accusative plural
  * the endings of the vocative plural
Here is the declension of the Greek word ἡ ἐλπίς meaning _the hope_.

* * *

#####  Useful tip!

In the third declension, masculine and feminine nouns have the same endings.

#####  Keep and eye out!

In masculine and feminine nouns, the **vocative** singular is identical in
form to the nominative singular:

  * when the nominative singular ends in -ξ or -ψ
  * when the nominative singular ends in -ν or -ρ and accents the ultima
Otherwise the nominative singular stays as the stem alone, with any final
letter dropped (e.g.ἐλπι)

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## Third declension: vowel stem

There are third declension nouns with vowel stems acting differently from
those with consonant stems. These include, for example:

  * ἡ πόλις, _the city_, with a stem in -**ι**
  * τό ἄστυ, _the city_, with a stem in -**υ**

* * *

##### ἡ πόλις: The city    τό ἄστυ: The city

**Singular** | **Singular**  
---|---  
Nom. | ἡ πόλις | τό ἄστυ  
Gen. | τῆς πόλ**εως** | τοῦ ἄστ**εως**  
Dat. | τῇ πόλ**ει** | τῷ ἄστ**ει**  
Acc. | τὴν πόλιν | τό ἄστυ  
Voc. | ὦ πόλι | ὦ ἄστυ  
**Plural** | **Plural**  
Nom. | αἱ πόλεις | τά ἄστη  
Gen. | τῶν πόλ**εων** | τῶν ἄστ**εων**  
Dat. | ταῖς πόλ**εσι(ν)** | τοῖς ἄστ**εσἱ(ν)**  
Acc. | τὰς πόλεις | τά ἄστη  
Voc. | ὦ πόλεις | ὦ ἄστη

fields.content:
![](/static/images/new_thuc.png) ![](/static/images/glasses.svg)

> _Don't leave now. Let's renew our vowels!_ Thucydides _(ca 460 - 395 BC)_

### Boeotia

![](/static/images/map_war_small.png)

The Athenians defeat the Boeotians and become their masters.

## ...previously in the Pentecontaetia

The Athenians defeat the Corinthians, who return home.

## Now in the Pentecontaetia...

The Athenians begin work on a long τό τεῖχος, a wall reaching the sea. They
also advance to engage the Peloponnesians in Boeotia. After heavy loss on both
sides, the Spartans win and return home. Later the Athenians return to Boeotia
and, once they have defeated their army, they become masters of the land.
Aegina also surrenders to the power of the Athenians.

(Summary of Thuc. 1.107-108)

Now that you've got some context, let's look at third declension nouns with
vowel stems!  
  
**Click the arrow to start learning!**

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## Third declension: vowel stem

There are also third declension nouns with a stems ending in **dipthongs**.
For example:

  * ἡ ναῦς, _the ship_, with a stem in -**αυ**
  * ὁ βασιλεύς, _the king_, with a stem in -**ευ**
  * ὁ βοῦς, _the buffalo_, with a stem in -**ου**

* * *

##### ἡ ναῦς: The ship    ὁ βασιλεύς: The king     ὁ βοῦς: The buffalo

**Singular** | **Singular** | **Singular**  
---|---|---  
Nom. | ἡ ναῦς | ὁ βασιλεύς | ὁ βοῦς  
Gen. | τῆς νεώς | τοῦ βασιλέως | τοῦ βοός  
Dat. | τῇ νηί | τῷ βασιλεῖ | τῷ βοί  
Acc. | τὴν ναῦν | τὸν βασιλέα | τὸν βοῦν  
Voc. | ὦ ναῦ | ῷ βασιλεῦ | ῷ βοῦ  
**Plural** | **Plural** | **Plural**  
Nom. | αἱ νῆες | οἱ βασιλῆς | οἱ βόες  
Gen. | τῶν νεῶν | τῶν βασιλέων | τῶν βοῶν  
Dat. | ταῖς ναυσί(ν) | τοῖς βασιλεῦσι(ν) | τοῖς βουσί  
Acc. | τὰς ναῦς | τοὺς βασιλέας | τοὺς βοῦς  
Voc. | ὦ νῆες | ῷ βασιλῆς | ῷ βόες

> _I'm not perfect, I'm just the father of scientific history._ Thucydides
_(ca 460 - 395 BC)_

# Imperfect Indicative Active

* * *

Now that you are familiar with the present and future indicative active,
you're ready to learn the **imperfect indicative active**!

* * *

## In this Section

New Skills New Vocab Sparta and Athens, allies no longer.

  1. Identify imperfect indicative active verbs.
  2. Conjugate imperfect indicative active verbs.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## Imperfect Indicative Active

As you now know:

  * The **imperfect tense** describes an action in the past with progressive aspect (i.e. the action took place over a period of time). 
  * The **indicative mood** is used for factual statements and questions.
  * The **active voice** means the subject of the verb is performing the action.

* * *

### Examples of the Imperfect in English

I **was grading** exams, when suddenly I heard thunder.

Emily **was drinking** tea all morning.

The ships **were sailing** at top speed.

Notice how, in these examples, the verbs took place over a period of time --
i.e. they express **progressive aspect**. If the sentences were simply "I
graded exams", "Emily drank coffee", and "The ships sailed", their verbs would
_not_ belong in the Imperfect tense. This is because "graded", "drank", and
"sailed" would indicate simple, one-time actions.

* * *

### Tips

##### Keep an eye out!

Remember that unlike English verbs, **the subject of the Greek verb is implied
by the verb's ending**. Therefore, it is not necessary for it to be
accompanied by the personal pronouns such as _I, You, He/She/It, We, You,
They_.

##### Imperfect Indicative Active, _To have_

**Singular**  
---  
1st | I  | was having  
2nd | You | were having  
3rd | He/She/It | was having | **Plural**  
1st | We | were having  
2nd | You | were having  
3rd | They | were having

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### Thucydides

![](/static/images/thuc.png)

The Spartans and the Athenians are no longer friends...but were they ever?

## ...previously in the Pentecontaetia

The Athenians grew less popular by demanding monetary and military
contributions from the alliance.

## Now in the Pentecontaetia...

The Spantans, finding it difficult to supress the revolt of the Helots on
their own, call for Athenian help. Cimon and his troups are sent to help
Sparta, but, upon their arrival, they are rudely dismissed by Κίμωνοἱ
Λακεδαιμόνιοι, the Spartans. This is because the Spartans are suddenly afraid
that the Athenians, after having helped, might demand political changes. The
Athenians take offense at this act and decide to renounce their alliance with
Sparta in favor for one with Argos, Sparta's enemy!

(Summary of Thuc. 1.102)

Now that you've got some context, let's look at third declension nouns!  
  
**Click the arrow to start learning!**

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
#### Imperfect Indicative Active

To form the Imperfect Indicative Active:

  1. **Take the present tense form**, also known as the first "principle part."  
e.g. λύω

  2. **Remove the ending** (-ω) to get the the present stem.   
e.g. λύ-

  3. **Add a ἐ- in front**. This prefix is called the "Past Indicative Augment".   
e.g. ἔλυ-

  4. **Add the endings** from the table to indicate person and number. Notice that these are different than the ending you use for the present and future tenses!   
e.g. ἔλυον, _I was untying_ -- or -- ἔλυομεν, _We were untying_.

* * *

For example:

ἔ

* * *

|  λυ

* * *

|  ον

* * *  
  
---|---|---  
**Augment**  
|  **Stem**  
|  **Ending**  
  
  
###  Here's a Clue!

Be on the look out for verbs that begin with an ἐ. When a verb gets an ἐ as a
prefix, this ἐ is called the **past indicative augment** because it only
occurs when: 1 The verb indicates a **past** action 2 The verb is in the
**indicative** mood.  
  
If you see a verb without the Past Indicative Augument, this is a good sign
that it's in another tense and voice.

### λύω, _I untie_

Imperfect Indicative Active -- ἔλυον, _I was untying_

Person | Singular | Plural  
---|---|---  
1st | ἔλυ**ον** | ἔλυ**ομεν**  
2nd | ἔλυ**ες** | ἔλυ**ετε**  
3rd | ἔλυ**ε(ν)** | ἔλυ**ον**

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### εἰμί, _I am_

Imperfect Indicative Active -- ἧν, _I was (being)_

**Singular**  
---  
1st | ἧν | I was (being)  
2nd | ἧσθα | You were (being)  
3rd | ἧν | He/She/It was (being) | **Plural**  
1st | ἧμεν | We were (being)  
2nd | ἧτε | You were (being)  
3rd | ἧσαν | They were (being)  
  
## Imperfect Indicative Active of _To Be_

The verb _To Be_ is **irregular**, meaning it does not follow the usual
conventions.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## Characteristics of Greek Nouns

Every Greek noun will have these 3 important characteristics:

  1. **Gender**: Masculine, Feminine, or Neuter
  2. **Number**: Singular or Plural
  3. **Case**: Nominative, Genitive, Dative, Accusative or Vocative

* * *

### Cases in English

While Gender and Number may be easy concepts to grasp, Case can be tricky for
uninflected-language speakers. Case indicates the change in the ending of a
word according to its function in the sentence. Though English is largely
uninflected, some words do change according to their function.

#### Example

> _**Who** am I?_

"Who" is in the **nominative** case, because it is the subject.

> _I have seen the man **whom** I admire._

"Whom" is in **accusative** case, because it is the direct object.

Here, English adds an "m" to indicate how "who" functions in the sentence.
With an "m", it's the direct object, without, it's the subject.

![](/static/images/new_thuc.png) ![](/static/images/glasses.svg)

> _English also does this with personal pronouns: **She** walks the dog
(subject), or does the dog walk **her**? (direct object)_ Thucydides

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
![](/static/images/new_thuc.png) ![](/static/images/glasses.svg)

> _Think about yourself as a detective -- in Ancient Greek, you're always
trying to solve the case._ Thucydides

## Case

The last -- but arguably most important -- thing to remember about Greek nouns
is that their ending changes according to the case they are in. The case of a
Greek noun indicates its grammatical relation to the rest of the sentence
(i.e., subject, direct object, etc.).

* * *

### Example

> _Thucydides describes the war._

_Thucydides_ is the **subject or nominative** of the verb _describes_, while
_the war_ is the **direct object or accusative** of the sentence.

* * *

In Greek there are **5 main cases** and it really helps to remember which
**order** they are in:

  1. **Nominative**
  2. **Genitive**
  3. **Dative**
  4. **Accusative**
  5. **Vocative**

In Greek, the _ending of a noun_ will always indicate which case it is in.
Indeed, both the definite article of a noun and the noun's ending will vary
according to case. The stem of the noun, however, always remains the same.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
![](/static/images/new_thuc.png) ![](/static/images/glasses.svg)

> _It's time to get down with nouns._ Thucydides

## Introduction to Thucydides and Nouns, naturally

* * *

In your journey to learn the basics of the Ancient Greek language you will be
guided by me, **Thucydides**, best known as the author of the renowned
_History of the Peloponnesian War_. You'll learn from examples in Greek from
this famous historical work, contextualized by snippets of my account in
English. By the end of this course, **you will feel comfortable reading
Thucydides in Ancient Greek!**

* * *

### You're going to learn

   4 New Skills           10 New Words           Thuc's Bio and bird's eye
view of the Peloponnesian War

  1. Identify the gender of a noun (feminine, masculine, neuter).
  2. Identify the number of a noun (singular, plural). 
  3. Understand the grammatical function of a case
  4. Identify Greek definite articles.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
![](/static/images/new_thuc.png) ![](/static/images/glasses.svg)

> _I may not like parsely, but I do like a parse tree._ Thucydides

## Building Parse Trees for Nouns

* * *

### What's a parse tree, you ask?

A **parse tree** is a way to represent that you understand the grammar of a
greek sentence. If one word _depends_ on another, it goes below it on the
tree. Simple as pie. Read on to learn your first rule of dependency!

[ { "id": 1, "head": 2, "relation": "ATR", "value": "οἱ", "pos": "article" },
{ "id": 2, "head": 0, "relation": "SBJ", "value": "Ἀθηναῖοι", "pos": "noun" }
]

### Try it yourself!

  1. Click on οἱ ("the"), the dependent.
  2. Click on Ἀθηναῖοι ("Athenians"), the parent.
  3. Profit.

* * *

### Wait, what did I just do?

You just demonstrated you understand that in this fragment, οἱ Ἀθηναῖοι, the
Athenians, belong together because:

* * *

  * οἱ _depends upon_ Ἀθηναῖοι, because they agree in Case, Number, and Gender (both are Masculine, Plural, Nominative).

* * *

That's it! Here's your first rule to learn on your quest for parse tree
proficiency:

**1\. Whenever you see a definite article and a noun that it agrees with, that definite article should be directly below it on a parse tree.**

Keep that in mind as you try the next couple exercises.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## Number

Just like it is in English, every Greek noun is either **singular** or
**plural**. As you learned earlier, the best way of determining the number of
a noun is to look at its _definite article_ and _ending_.

Notice how the _definite article_ and the _ending_ change from singular to
plural, while the _stem_ remains unchanged:

### Feminine

Singular | Plural  
---|---  
_ἡ_ ἡμέρ_α_  
the day  |  _αἱ_ ἡμέρ_αι_  
the days  
  
### Masculine

Singular | Plural  
---|---  
_ὁ_ πόλεμ_ος_  
the war  |  _οἱ_ πόλεμ_οι_  
the wars  
  
### Neuter

Singular | Plural  
---|---  
_τό_ ἔργ_ον_  
the work  |  _τά_ ἔργ_α_  
the works

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
![](/static/images/new_thuc.png) ![](/static/images/glasses.svg)

> _Who am I? Who are YOU?_ Thucydides

## Who was Thucydides?

Thucydides (circa 460 BC to 395 BC) was born in the great city of Athens. He
was ὁ ἀνήρ ᾿Αθηναῖος, an Athenian man. At the age of 30, Thucydides survived
the plague of Athens, a devastating epidemic that killed many citizens. He was
sent to the island of Thasos soon after as ὁ στρατηγός, a general for the
Athenian army.

* * *

In the winter of that year, the city of Amphipolis was lost to οἱ
Λακεδαιμόνιοι, the Spartans, after an attack. Thucydides was blamed for this
defeat and sent into exile. He became a wanderer and traveled among the allies
of ἡ Πελοπόννησος, the Peloponnesus -- the large peninsula forming the south
of Greece.

* * *

In this capacity he observed the conflicts that had begun between the cities
of Athens and Sparta in 431 BC from the perspectives of both sides. Thucydides
was later called the father of 'scientific history' because he related the
causes and effects of the war in a factual manner with no reference to the
gods, as he himself outlines in the introduction to his work.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## Identifying the 3 characteristics of nouns

  1. To identify the **gender** of a noun, look at its _definite article_.
  2. To identify the **number** of a noun, look at its _definite article_ and its _ending_.
  3. To identify the **case** of a noun, look at its _definite article_, _stem_ and _ending_.

Let's take the Greek word for "day" again:

ἡ (the) ἡμέρα (Day)

ἡ

* * *

|  ἡμέρ

* * *

|  α

* * *  
  
---|---|---  
**Definite Article**  

* * *

The definite article, ἡ ("the"), tells us ἡμέρα is a _feminine_ (**gender**)
noun.  |  **Stem**  

* * *

The stem, ἡμέρ-, stays constant as we change the noun's number and case.  |
**Ending**  

* * *

The ending, -α, indicates this is a _singular_ (**number**) _nominative_
(**case**) noun.  
  
This means that ἡ ἡμέρα is a _Feminine_, _Singular_, _Nominative_ noun.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## Gender

Every noun in Greek is either **masculine**, **feminine** or **neuter**. The
gender of a noun is an aspect of the word's grammar, so try not getting it
confused with biological sex -- often the two will not match!

As you learned in the previous slide, you can **identify the gender of a
noun** by its _definite article_ preceeding the word.

* * *

### Feminine

_ἡ_ ἡμέρα

the Day

* * *

ἡ is the definite article for feminine nouns.

### Masculine

_ὁ_ πόλεμος_

the War

* * *

ὁ is the definite article for masculine nouns.

### Neuter

_τό_ ἔργον

the Work

* * *

τό is the definite article for neuter nouns.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## How Greek Nouns Work

Just like many modern languages (for example, German and Russian) **Greek is
an inflected language**.**

This means that the **endings** of nouns, pronouns, adjectives and verbs
**change to reflect their relationship with other words**.

* * *

Take, for example, the Greek word for "day":

ἡ ἡμέρα

The Day

By looking at ἡ ἡμέρα, you may already identify its 3 characteristics:  
  

  1. Gender: _Feminine_
  2. Number: _Singular_
  3. Case: _Nominative_

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
##### ὁ ἡ τό, The

Case | Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | ὁ | ἡ | τό  
Gen. | τοῦ | τῆς | τοῦ  
Dat. | τῷ | τῇ | τῷ  
Acc. | τόν | τήν | τό  
Voc. | - | - | -  
**Plural**  
Nom. | οἱ | αἱ | τά  
Gen. | τῶν | τῶν | τῶν  
Dat. | τοῖς | ταῖς | τοῖς  
Acc. | τούς | τάς | τά  
Voc. | - | - | -  
  
## Definite Articles

Greek has articles that in meaning are roughly the equivalent of the English
**"the"**. The Greek article takes on different form for the different
genders, numbers and cases. Articles always **agree** with the nouns they
refer to, meaning that they take the same gender, number, and case of the
noun.

* * *

#####  Useful tip!

Note the change in accent from an acute to a circumflex in the genitive and
dative, both singular and plural.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
##### Present Indicative Active, _To have_

| **Singular** | **Plural**  
---|---|---  
1st | I | have | We | have  
2nd | You | have | You (all) | have  
3rd | He/She/It | has | They | have  
  
Conjugating verbs in English is relatively simple. In Greek, the verbs
themselves, instead of a subject like "I" or "You", commonly indicates who is
performing the action of the verb.

## How Greek Verbs work

Just like nouns, Greek verbs are inflected and just like nouns they add an
ending to their stem to produce their various forms. While the patterns for
nouns are called declensions (and the noun is declined), the verb forms fall
into **conjugations** (so the verb is **conjugated**).

Most Greek verbs will have these 5 important characteristics:

  1. **Person**
  2. **Number**
  3. **Tense**
  4. **Mood**
  5. **Voice**

* * *

##### How does Greek differ from English?

Unlike English verbs, the subject of the Greek verb is implied by the verb's
ending. Therefore, it is not necessary for it to be accompanied by the
personal pronouns _I, You, He/She/It, We, You, They_.

For example: The English _I have_ can be translated either ἐγώ ἔχω or, more
commonly, simply ἔχω.

Soon you will be able to identify the **5 characteristics of Greek verbs**
yourself! Click onthe arrow to find out how.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
Characteristics of Verbs:

1\. Person

2\. Number

3\. Tense

4\. Mood

5\. Voice

  

##### Present Indicative Active, _To have_

| **Singular** | **Plural**  
---|---|---  
1st | I | have | We | have  
2nd | You | have | You (all) | have  
3rd | He/She/It | has | They | have  
  
## Voice

Voice defines how the subject of the verb is involved in the action of the
verb. Greek has three voices:

  1. **Active**  
If the subject is performing the action, the voice is active.  
For example: _I scare (someone)_.  
  

  2. **Passive**  
If the subject is receiving the action from an outside agency, the voice is
passive.  
For example: _I am scared (by something)._  
  

  3. **Middle**  
If the subject is performing the action with personal involvement, the voice
is middle.  
For example _I am frightened_.  
  

You will learn each voice in depth later in the course.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
Characteristics of Verbs:

1\. Person

2\. Number

3\. Tense

4\. Mood

5\. Voice

  

##### Present Indicative Active, _To have_

| **Singular** | **Plural**  
---|---|---  
1st | I | have | We | have  
2nd | You | have | You (all) | have  
3rd | He/She/It | has | They | have  
  
## Mood

The mood of a verb indicates whether a sentence is a factual statement,
hypothetical, wishful, a commanding statement and so on. In Greek there are
four moods:

  1. **Indicative**  
Mood for factual statements and questions.  
For example: _I am a soldier_.  
  

  2. **Subjunctive**  
Mood for hypothetical and other types of statements.  
For example: _If I were a soldier..._.  
  

  3. **Optative**  
Mood for conditional statements.  
For example: _I may be a soldier_.  
  

  4. **Imperative**  
Mood for commanding statements.  
For example: _Be a soldier!_  
  

You will learn each mood in depth later in the course.

fields.content:
![](/static/images/new_thuc.png) ![](/static/images/glasses.svg)

> _Greek out! It's verb time._ Thucydides _(ca 460 - 395 BC)_

### How Verbs Work

* * *

Now that you have learned second declension nouns, it's a good time to become
familiar with the **Greek verbs**!

* * *

#### In this Section

New Skills New Vocab Building the walls of Athens

  1. Identify the person of a verb.
  2. Identify the number of a verb.
  3. Identify the tense of a verb.
  4. Identify the mood of a verb.
  5. Identify the voice of a verb.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
Characteristics of Verbs:

1\. Person

2\. Number

3\. Tense

4\. Mood

5\. Voice

  

##### Present Indicative Active, _To have_

| **Singular** | **Plural**  
---|---|---  
1st | I | have | We | have  
2nd | You | have | You (all) | have  
3rd | He/She/It | has | They | have  
  
Let's take a closer look at a verb's characteristics.

## Person

"Person" describes who is performing the action of the verb.

  * If the subject of the verb is **I** or **we**, the verb is in the **first person**.
  * If the subject is **you**, the verb is in the **second person**.
  * If the subject is **he/she/it** or **they**, the verb is in the **third person**.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
Characteristics of Verbs:

1\. Person

2\. Number

3\. Tense

4\. Mood

5\. Voice

  

##### Present Indicative Active, _To have_

| **Singular** | **Plural**  
---|---|---  
1st | I | have | We | have  
2nd | You | have | You (all) | have  
3rd | He/She/It | has | They | have  
  
## Number

The verbs that have a person can be either singular or plural.

  * If the subject of the verb is **I**, **you** or **he/she/it**, the verb is **singular**.
  * If the subject of the verb is **we**, **you (all)** or **they**, the verb is **plural**.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### Pausanias, the military leader of Sparta

  

![](/static/images/pausanias.JPG)

I am most famous for leading the Hellenes during the decisive battle of
Plataea against the Persians.

## ...previously in the Pentecontaetia

Themistocles revealed to the Spartans the truth about the wall.

## Now in the Pentecontaetia...

The wall is completed in a very short period of time, for the foundations are
laid with stones of all kinds, pieces of columns, tombs, and sculptures. ὁ
Θεμιστοκλῆς, Themistocles, insists that the Piraeus, the port of Athens, is
also fortified. He, in fact, can foresee the great power that Athens will gain
by being a city of naval people.

Meanwhile, while the Spartans are still supreme among οἱ Ἕλληνες, the
Hellenes, the Spartan military leader Pausanias leads τό ναυτικόν, a fleet of
fifty Greek ships and conquers Cyprus and Byzantium.

(Summary of Thuc. 1.93-94)

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
Characteristics of Verbs:

1\. Person

2\. Number

3\. Tense

4\. Mood

5\. Voice

  

##### Present Indicative Active, _To have_

| **Singular** | **Plural**  
---|---|---  
1st | I | have | We | have  
2nd | You | have | You (all) | have  
3rd | He/She/It | has | They | have  
  
## Tense

The tense of a verb always conveys information about _aspect_ and sometimes
information about _aspect and time_.

* * *

### What does tense tell us?

The **time** of a verb indicates whether the verb is present, past or future.
For example _I am_, _I was_, _I will be_.

The **aspect** of a verb indicates _how_ the situation occurs in time. For
example, did the action occur once, over a period of time, or repeatedly?
Aspect can often answer these kinds of questions.

* * *

### Summary of the Tenses

In Greek there are 7 tenses. **You'll learn about each one in detail later!**

  1. **Present**  
Describes an action in the present time with progressive aspect (i.e. the
action is still taking place).  
For example: _I am fighting_.  
  

  2. **Future**  
Describes an action in the future time with either simple aspect (i.e. fixed
moment in time), for example _I will fight_ or progressive aspect.  
For example: _I will be fighting_.  
  

  3. **Perfect**  
Describes an action in the present time with completed aspect (i.e. fixed
moment in time that has come to an end).  
For example: _I have fought_.  
  

  4. **Pluperfect**  
Describes an action in the past time with completed aspect.  
For example: _I had fought_.  
  

  5. **Future Perfect**  
Describes an action in future time with completed aspect.  
For example: _I shall have fought_.  
  

  6. **Imperfect**  
Describes an action in the past time with progressive aspect.  
For example: _I was fighting_.  
  

  7. **Aorist**  
Describes an action in the past time with simple aspect.  
For example: _I fell_.

## Building Parse Trees for Nouns

* * *

### What's the next step?

Nouns can often be found in the company of _adjectives_ that describe them,
_determiners_ (or definite articles) that delimit them, _relative clauses_ and
prepositional phrases that make their meaning more specific. These descriptive
elements take the name of **attribute (ATR)**. It helps to imagine them as the
leaves on the branches.

"id": 2, "head": 1, "relation": "Subj", "value": "", "pos": "noun" }, { "id":
3, "head": 2, "relation": "Atr", "value": "", "pos": "article" } ]

  
  

### Try it yourself!

  1. Click on the ATR word circle.
  2. Then click on the SUBJ circle, on which the ATR depends.
  3. If the circles fill up with color, your tree is complete!
  4. Create any other dependencies you see.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
UPDATE ME!
UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## Building Parse Trees for Nouns

* * *

### Let's get started, shall we?

It all starts with the **root**. The root is the starting point on which you
build the tree.

When you have taken a good look at the sentence you are working on, you must
identify the trunk of your tree. This is called the **predicate (PRED)**. The
PRED is a word in the sentence that does not depend on any other word and
around which the sentence revolves. The PRED is the verb of a sentence, as it
shapes the form of the main constituents in the sentence.

[ { "id": 1, "head": 0, "relation": "PRED", "value": "PRED", "pos": "verb" } ]

Identifying the PRED is the first step to building your own tree! The PRED
will always appear as a red circle, because the PRED is a verb.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
![](/static/images/new_thuc.png) ![](/static/images/glasses.svg)

> _I may not like parsely, but I do like a parse tree._ Thucydides

## Building Parse Trees for Nouns

* * *

### What's a parse tree, you ask?

A **parse tree** is a way to represent that you understand the grammar and
function of a Greek sentence. The act of building parse trees is called
**treebanking**.

* * *

### Why is it useful?

Treebanking can really help you understand the meaning of difficult sentences
and, by building parse trees, you can store your interpretation of any
sentence so that both yourself and other scholars can benefit from it in the
future!

* * *

### So, how does it work?

Just imagine a tree that hangs upside down – that’s what your parse tree will
look like. The trees can be big or small and have many or few branches,
depending on the length of the sentence.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## Building Parse Trees for Nouns

* * *

### What's the final step?

In order to build complete basic trees, the last thing you should learn about
it are **adverbials (ADV)**. ADVs specify the circumstances under which an
event expressed by a verb takes place. An ADV can be an _adverb_, a
_prepositional phrase_, _participle_ or _subordinate clause_. In a tree the
ADV will depend on the word to which it is referred. Remember, ADV are always
optional constituents, in the sense that a sentence can have some meaning even
without them (which does not mean that they are not important, but that you
can conceive of a context where they might be left out).

[ { "id": 1, "head": 0, "relation": "Pred", "value": "", "pos": "verb" }, {
"id": 2, "head": 1, "relation": "Subj", "value": "", "pos": "noun" }, { "id":
3, "head": 2, "relation": "Atr", "value": "", "pos": "article" }, { "id": 4,
"head": 1, "relation": "Adv", "value": "", "pos": "adverb" }, { "id": 5,
"head": 1, "relation": "Obj", "value": "", "pos": "noun" } ]

  
  

### Try it yourself!

  1. Click on the ADV word circle.
  2. Then click on the PRED circle, on which the ADV depends.
  3. If the circles fill up with color, your tree is complete!
  4. Create any other dependencies you see.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## Building Parse Trees for Nouns

* * *

### What's the next step?

Then, you can start giving your tree branches. A particularly important branch
is the **subject (SUBJ)** of the sentence. The subject depends on the PRED and
often describes who/what performs the action of the sentence. The SUBJ is
often a noun.

The subject is usually in the nominative case, but you will learn that in a
few other constructions it can also be in the genitive or accusative case.

[ { "id": 1, "head": 0, "relation": "Pred", "value": "", "pos": "verb" }, {
"id": 2, "head": 1, "relation": "Subj", "value": "", "pos": "noun" } ]

  
  

### Try it yourself!

  1. Click on the SUBJ word circle. The SUBJ circle is always blue.
  2. Then click on the PRED circle, on which the SUBJ depends.
  3. If the circles fill up with color, your tree is complete!

{ "id": 2, "head": 3, "relation": "Sbj", "value": "man", "pos": "noun" }, {
"id": 3, "head": 0, "relation": "Pred", "value": "eats", "pos": "verb" }, {
"id": 4, "head": 5, "relation": "Atr", "value": "an", "pos": "article" }, {
"id": 5, "head": 3, "relation": "Obj", "value": "apple", "pos": "noun" } ]

Build your own parse tree! A parse tree is a way to show that you understand
the grammar and function of a Greek sentence. Treebanking can really help you
make sense of the meaning of difficult Greek sentences. The root is the
starting point on which you build the "upside-down" tree. All you have to do
is figure out which words in the sentence "depend" on other words. Take the
English sentence: _The man eats an apple._ The action verb of the sentences is
_eats_, while the subject is _man_. The object is _apple_. Therefore, _man_
and _apple_ depend on _eats_. The article _The_ depends on the word _man_, so
in a tree it would be placed under it.

1) Click a word circle     2) Click the word circle it depends on     3) When
all circles are filled with color, your tree is complete!     **See further
explanation below.**

[ { "id": 1, "head": 2, "relation": "Atr", "value": "The", "pos": "article" },
{ "id": 2, "head": 3, "relation": "Sbj", "value": "gods", "pos": "noun" }, {
"id": 3, "head": 0, "relation": "Pred", "value": "watch", "pos": "verb" }, {
"id": 4, "head": 5, "relation": "Atr", "value": "all", "pos": "article" }, {
"id": 5, "head": 3, "relation": "Obj", "value": "men", "pos": "noun" } ]

**Are you wondering what those words above the circles mean?** They indicate the relations between words. It may help you to become familiar with just a few of these. **Pred** describes the predicate - the verb of the sentence (for example, watch). **Subj** is the subject: it depends on the _Pred_ and often describes who/what performs the action of the sentence (for example, gods). **Obj** is the object: it depends on the _Pred_ and represents the element in the sentence that is being acted upon (for example, men). And **Atr** describes the attribute, or a descriptive element in the sentence, which could be an article or adjective that depends on a noun (for example, the or all). It's that easy!

# Welcome!

We are trying to test which methods of teaching Ancient Greek are most
effective and engaging for learners. You can help us by spending a little time
with our eLearning environment. In the process, you'll get to interact with

historical account of the battles fought between the Athenians and the
Spartans during the 5th century BC.

screen. Please be sure to do this before exiting, so we can ask you a couple
of closing questions.

### εἰμί, _I am_

Present Indicative Active

Person |  |  |  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
1st | εἰμί | I am  
2nd | εἶ | You are  
3rd | ἐστί(ν) | He/She/It is | **Plural**  
1st | ἐσμέν | We are  
2nd | ἐστέ | You are  
3rd | εἰσί(ν) | They are  
  
## Present Indicative Active of _To Be_

The verb _To Be_ is **irregular**, meaning it does not follow the usual
conventions.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
##### Present Indicative Active, _To have_

| **Singular** | **Plural**  
---|---|---  
1st | I | have | We | have  
2nd | You | have | You (all) | have  
3rd | He/She/It | has | They | have  
  
## Present Indicative Active

As you now know:

  * The**present tense**describes an action in the present time with progressive aspect (i.e. the action is still taking place). 
  * The**indicative mood**is used for factual statements and questions.
  * The**active voice**means the subject of the verb is performing the action.

* * *

##### Remember: Greek implies the subject of the verb in the verb's
conjugation!

Remember that unlike English verbs, the subject of the Greek verb is implied
by the verb's ending. Therefore, it is not necessary for it to be accompanied
by the personal pronouns _I, You, He/She/It, We, You, They_.

For example: The English _I have_ can be translated either ἐγώ ἔχω or, more
commonly, simply  ἔχω.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
![](/static/images/new_thuc.png) ![](/static/images/glasses.svg)

> _"Indicative" comes from Latin, _indicare_, which means to declare
something. I declare Latin to be useless compared to almighty Greek!_
Thucydides _(ca 460 - 395 BC)_

# Present Indicative Active

* * *

Now that you are familiar with the 5 characteristics of verbs, start by
learning the **present indicative active**!

* * *

## In this Section

New Skills New Vocab The fate of Pausanias

  1. Identify present indicative active verbs.
  2. Conjugate present indicative active verbs.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### Thucydides

![](/static/images/thuc.png)

The power is going to your head, Pausanias!

## ...previously in the Pentecontaetia

Pausanias won Cyprus and Byzantium with the help of fifty Greek ships.

## Now in the Pentecontaetia...

Pausanias grows arrogant and unpopular among οἱ Ἕλληνες, the Hellenes, because
he is acting more like a despot than a general. The Greek allies request that
the leadership be handed to the Athenians. On his return to Sparta, Pausanias
is tried for his acts of oppression, but acquitted and found not guilty.
However, he is not restored to his command and οἱ Λακεδαιμόνιοι, the Spartans
do not return into battle.

As the new leaders, the Athenians form a new anti-Persian alliance and
determine which Greek cities are to contribute money and ships against them.

(Summary of Thuc. 1.95-96)

Now that you've got some context, let's look at the Present Indicative Active
verbs!  
  
**Click the arrow to start learning!**

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### λύω, _I untie_

Present Indicative Active

Person |  |  |  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
1st | λύ**ω** | I untie  
2nd | λύ**εις** | You untie  
3rd | λύ**ει** | He/She/It unties | **Plural**  
1st | λύ**ομεν** | We untie  
2nd | λύ**ετε** | You untie  
3rd | λύ**ουσι(ν)** | They untie  
  
## Present Indicative Active

To form the present indicative active, **identify the present tense stem by
removing the variable ending \- ω**. Add the endings from the table to
indicate person and number.

* * *

For example:

λύ

* * *

|  ω

* * *  
  
---|---  
**Stem**  
|  **Ending**  
  
  
##### Learn something Nu!

The letter ν at the end of the third person plural is called **nu-movable**.
It may be added to certain endings when/if the following word begins with a
vowel or at the end of a sentence.

And...remember the accent rules? They also apply to verbs!

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
#### τό ἔργον,ου: The work, of the work

**Singular** | **Plural**  
---|---  
Nom. | τό ἔργ**ον** | τά ἔργ**α**  
Gen. | τοῦ ἔργ**ου** | τῶν ἔργ**ων**  
Dat. | τῷ ἔργ**ῳ** | τοῖς ἔργ**οις**  
Acc. | τό ἔργ**ον** | τά ἔργ**α**  
Voc. | ῷ ἔργ**ον** | ῷ ἔργ**α**  
  
## Second declension continued...

And now here is an example of a neuter second declension noun: τό ἔργον
meaning _the work_.

* * *

### Neuter Nouns are a Special Case

In all neuter nouns, **the accusative and the vocative are the same as the
nominative**. This works for both singular and plural.

* * *

### Examples

Notice how τὸ χωρίον remains in the same form in these two sentences, even
though it is the object of the first sentence and the subject in the second.

#### Neuter noun in the Accusative

βίᾳ γὰρ ἂν εἷλον **τὸ χωρίον**.

_For otherwise they would have taken **the place** by force._ ([Thuc
1.102.4](/reader/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0003.tlg001.perseus-grc1:1.102.4))

#### Neuter noun in the Nominative

...ἐπειδὴ **τὸ χωρίον** βίᾳ οὐχ ἡλίσκετο...

_...but since **the place** was not conquered by force..._ ([Thuc
1.102.6](/reader/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0003.tlg001.perseus-grc1:1.102.6))

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
##### Second Declension

Case | Singular | Plural  
---|---|---  
**Feminine/Masculine**  
Nom. | -ος | -οι  
Gen. | -ου | -ων  
Dat. | -ῳ | -οις  
Acc. | -ον | -ους  
Voc. | -ε | -οι  
**Neuter**  
Nom. | -ον | -α  
Gen. | -ου | -ων  
Dat. | -ῳ | -οις  
Acc. | -ον | -α  
Voc. | -ον | -α  
  
#### The Second Declension in the Pentecontaetia

The following is an example of how Thucydides himself makes use of second
declension nouns in the Pentecontaetia.

[...] ὁ Θεμιστοκλῆς |  **τοῖς Ἀθηναίοις** |  κρύφα |  πέμπει [...]  
---|---|---|---  
[...] Themistocles  |  **to the Athenians** |  secretly  |  sent [...]  
(Nominative)  |  **(Dative)**   |  |  (Verb)  
-- _The History of the Peloponnesian War_, 1.91.3

Keep Reading »

![](/static/images/thuc.png)

τοῖς Ἀθηναίοις is a masculine, plural second declension noun in the dative
case.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## Second declension

Second declension nouns either have the nominative singular ending in -ος for
masculine and, less frequently, feminine nouns, or the ending in -ον for the
neuter. Here is the declension for the Greek word ὁ λόγος meaning _the word_.

##### ὁ λόγος,ου: The word

**Singular** | **Plural**  
---|---  
Nom. | ὁ λόγ**ος** | οἱ λόγ**οι**  
Gen. | τοῦ λόγ**ου** | τῶν λόγ**ων**  
Dat. | τῷ λόγ**ῳ** | τοῖς λόγ**οις**  
Acc. | τόν λόγ**ον** | τούς λόγ**ους**  
Voc. | ῷ λόγ**ε** | ῷ λόγ**οι**  
  
#####  The Genitive is the key!

Remember that to decline you must take the genitive singular, remove the
ending to get the stem and add the correct ending to form the other cases.

### Second Declension

* * *

declension nouns, you can expand your vocabulary by learning **second
declension nouns**!

* * *

#### In this Section

New Skills New Vocab Themistocles goes to Sparta.

  1. Identify second declension nouns ending in -ος.
  2. Identify second declension nouns ending in -ον.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### The Athenian wall

![](/static/images/wall.JPG)

* * *

The wall of Athens was built in 479 BC with the help of all its citizens,
including women and children.

## ...previously in the Pentecontaetia

The Greeks returned home after the war and the Athenians rebuilt their city
wall. Themistocles went to Sparta to cover up the truth about it.

## Now in the Pentecontaetia...

Themistocles lies to οἱ Λακεδαιμόνιοι, the Spartans, about the rebuilding of
the wall, and though wanting to believe him for the sake of friendship, the
Spartans are suspicious enough to send their men to Athens to check.
Meanwhile, ὁ Θεμιστοκλῆς, Themistocles is joined by two colleagues bringing
the news that the wall of Athens has been rebuilt. Themistocles decides to
break the news to the Spartans and tells them that the wall is only one of the
measures that Athens is taking to protects its own interests. The Spartans
listen and accept Themistocles' words with outward grace, but secret
annoyance...

(Summary of Thuc. 1.91-92)

Now that you've got some context, let's look at second declension nouns.  
**Click the arrow to start learning!**

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
##### Three-ending Adjectives of the First and Second Declension,
δίκαιος,δικαία,δίκαιον _righteous_

| Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | δίκαιος | δικαία | δίκαιον  
Gen. | δικαίου | δικαίας | δικαίου  
Dat. | δικαίῳ | δικαίᾳ | δικαίῳ | Acc. | δίκαιον | δικαίαν | δίκαιον | Voc. |
δίκαιε | δικαία | δίκαιον | **Plural**  
Nom. | δίκαιοι | δίκαιαι | δίκαια  
Gen. | δικαίων | δικαίων | δικαίων  
Dat. | δικαίοις | δικαίαις | δικαίοις  
Acc. | δικαίους | δικαίας | δίκαια  
Voc. | δίκαιοι | δίκαιαι | δίκαια  
  
#### How Greek Verbs work

Just like nouns, Greek verbs are inflected and just like nouns they add an
ending to their stem to produce their various forms. While the patterns for
nouns are called declensions (and the noun is declined), the verb forms fall
into **conjugations** (so the verb is **conjugated**).  
Most Greek verbs will have these 5 important characteristics:

  1. **Person**
  2. **Number**
  3. **Tense**
  4. **Mood**
  5. **Voice**

* * *

##### Useful tip!

Unlike English verbs, the subject of the Greek verb is implied by the verb's
ending. Therefore, it is not necessary for it to be accompanied by the
personal pronouns _I, You, He/She/It, We, You, They_.  
For example: The English _I have_ can be translated either ἐγώ ἔχω or, more
commonly, simply  ἔχω.

Soon you will be able to identify the **5 characteristics of Greek verbs**
yourself! Click onthe arrow to find out how.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## How First and Second Declension Adjectives work

Just like articles and nouns have gender, number and case, so do all the
adjectives. Like the article, **an adjective must agree in gender, number and
case with the noun it describes**.

However, this does not mean that the ending of the article and that of the
noun are always identical; there are exceptions where, though the adjective
and noun agree, the endings might look different (e.g. ἄδικος ψυχή, meaning
_an unjust soul_).

Adjectives agreeing with first and second declension nouns fall into two
groups:

  * **Three-ending Adjectives**  
There are separate sets of endings for each of the three genders.  
  

  * **Two-ending Adjectives**  
Masculine and Feminine nouns share one set of endings, while neuter has a
different set.  
  

* * *

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
![](/static/images/new_thuc.png) ![](/static/images/glasses.svg)

> _If an adjective comes up to you in a bar, you've got to decline that, too!_
Thucydides _(ca 460 - 395 BC)_

# Adjectives: First and Second Declension

* * *

Now is a good time to learn everything about **First and Second Declension
Adjectives**!

* * *

## In this Section

New Skills New Vocab Athenians still be gainin' that power.

  1. Identify and decline three-ending adjectives.
  2. Identify and decline two-ending adjectives.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### ἄδικος, ἄδικον -- _unjust_

Two-ending Adjective

| Masc./Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | ἄδικ**ος** | ἄδικ**ον**  
Gen. | ἀδίκ**ου** | ἄδίκ**ου**  
Dat. | ἀδίκ**ῳ** | ἀδίκ**ῳ** | Acc. | ἄδικ**ον** | ἄδικ**ον** | Voc. |
ἄδικ**ε** | ἄδικ**ον** | **Plural**  
Nom. | ἄδικ**οι** | ἄδικ**α**  
Gen. | ἀδίκ**ων** | ἀδίκ**ων**  
Dat. | ἀδίκ**οις** | ἀδίκ**οις**  
Acc. | ἀδίκ**ους** | ἄδικ**α**  
Voc. | ἄδικ**οι** | ἄδικ**α**  
  
## Two-ending Adjectives of the Second Declension

As you can see from the table, the adjective ἄδικος, ἄδικον has the same
endings as second declension nouns.

Example: τοῦ ἀδίκου ἀνθρώπου, meaning _of the unjust man._

##### Meet the Alpha Privative

The adjective **ἄ**δικος, meaning _unjust_ is the exact opposite in meaning of
δίκαιος meaning _just_. The clue is in the prefix **α**, also called _alpha
privative_, expressesing negation or absence.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### Cimon, Athenian military leader

![](/static/images/cimon.gif)

I am an Athenian statesman and general. I am also the son of Miltiades, the
hero of Marathon who died in disgrace.

## ...previously in the Pentecontaetia

The Athenians grew less popular by demanding monetary and military
contributions from the alliance.

## Now in the Pentecontaetia...

Under the Athenian military leader, Κίμων, Cimon, the Athenians and the allies
together defeat the Persians once again on the river Eurymedon. The Athenians
also manage to suppress the revolt of the Thracians by defeating them at sea
and landing on their island. However, they are defeated in Amphipolis while
they attempt to advance further into Thrace.

The defeated Thracians appeal to the Spartans, who, in turn, secretely promise
to assist them by invading Attica, the region encompassing Athens. But Spartan
aid is prevented by a terrible earthquake and by the revolt of the Helots.
Without the help of the Spartans, the Thacians are, therefore, forced to
surrender to οἱ Ἀθηναῖοι, the Athenians.

(Summary of Thuc. 1.100-101)

Now that you've got some context, let's look at the adjectives of the first
and second declensions!  
  
**Click the arrow to start learning!**

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### δίκαιος, δικαία, δίκαιον -- _just_

Three-ending Adjective

| Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | δίκαι**ος** | δικαί**α** | δίκαι**ον**  
Gen. | δικαί**ου** | δικαί**ας** | δικαί**ου**  
Dat. | δικαί**ῳ** | δικαί**ᾳ** | δικαί**ῳ** | Acc. | δίκαι**ον** | δικαί**αν**
| δίκαι**ον** | Voc. | δίκαι**ε** | δικαί**α** | δίκαι**ον** | **Plural**  
Nom. | δίκαι**οι** | δίκαι**αι** | δίκαι**α**  
Gen. | δικαί**ων** | δικαί**ων** | δικαί**ων**  
Dat. | δικαί**οις** | δικαί**αις** | δικαί**οις**  
Acc. | δικαί**ους** | δικαί**ας** | δίκαι**α**  
Voc. | δίκαι**οι** | δίκαι**αι** | δίκαι**α**  
  
## Three-ending Adjectives of the First and Second Declension

As you can see from the table, the adjective δίκαιος, δικαία, δίκαιον has the
same endings as first declension nouns in the feminine, and as second
declension nouns in the masculine and neuter.

Example: ὁ δίκαιος ἄνθρωπος, meaning _the just man._

##### Word Order and Adjectives

The meaning given to the article, noun, and its agreeing adjective can vary
slightly according to **word order**. So, you might not always find these
three components (article, noun, adjective) in the same sequence.

* * *

For example: ὁ ἀγαθὸς ἄνθρωπος means _the good man_, but ἄνθρωπος ὁ ἀγαθος
means _a man, the good one_

![](/static/images/new_thuc.png) ![](/static/images/glasses.svg)

> _Welcome to the fold, intrepid beta tester._ Thucydides

# Welcome!

We are trying to test which methods of teaching Ancient Greek are most
effective and engaging for learners. You can help us by spending a little time
with our eLearning environment. In the process, you'll get to interact with
text directly from Thucydides' _History of the Peloponnesian War_, a
historical account of the battles fought between the Athenians and the
Spartans during the 5th century BC.

At any point, you can click the **_Skip to Survey_** link at the top of the
screen. Please be sure to do this before exiting, so we can ask you a couple
of closing questions.

**Click the red top right corner of the screen to start!**
