fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
#### Future Indicative Active, _To have_

Person | Subject | Verb  
---|---|---  
**Singular**  
1st | I | will have  
2nd | You | will have  
3rd | He/She/It | will have | **Plural**  
1st | We | will have  
2nd | You | will have  
3rd | They | will have  
  
In English, we form the future by using the helping verb "will". In Ancient
Greek, however, the verb itself changes to reflect that it is in the future
tense.

## Future Indicative Active

As you now know:

  * The**future tense**describes an action in the future time with either simple aspect (i.e. fixed moment in time).
  * The**indicative mood**is used for factual statements and questions.
  * The**active voice**means the subject of the verb is performing the action.

* * *

#### Keep an eye out!

Remember that unlike English verbs, the subject of the Greek verb is implied
by the verb's ending. Therefore, it is not necessary for it to be accompanied
by the personal pronouns _I, You, He/She/It, We, You, They_.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### εἰμί, _I am_

Future Active Indicative -- ἔσομαι, _I will be_

Person | Singular | Plural  
---|---|---  
1st | ἔσ**ομαι** | ἐσ**όμεθα**  
2nd | ἔσ**ῃ** | ἔσ**εσθε**  
3rd | ἔσ**ται** | ἔσ**ονται**  
  
## Future Indicative Active of _To Be_

The verb _To Be_ is **irregular**, meaning it does not follow the usual
conventions.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### λύω, _I untie_

Future Indicative Active -- λύσω, _I will untie_

Person | Singular | Plural  
---|---|---  
1st | λύσ**ω** | λύσ**ομεν**  
2nd | λύσ**εις** | λύσ**ετε**  
3rd | λύσ**ει** | λύσ**ουσι(ν)**  
  
## Future Indicative Active

To form the future indicative active:

  1. **Take the present tense form**, also known as the first "principle part".   
e.g. λύω

  2. **Remove the ending** (-ω) to get the the present stem.   
e.g. λύ-

  3. **Add a σ** to get the future stem.   
e.g. λύσ-

  4. **Add the endings** from the table to indicate the person and number.   
e.g. λύσομεν, _We will untie_ -- or -- λύσεις, _You will untie_

The future then becomes the **second principle part** of a verb (while the
present is the first principle part).

* * *

The Parts of a Future Tense Verb

λύσ

* * *

|  ω

* * *  
  
---|---  
**Future Stem**  

* * *

The future stem is formed by taking the present tense stem λύ- and adding
**σ**.  |  **Ending**  

* * *

The endings of the future indicative active are **the same as those of the
present indicative active**.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## The Future Indicative Active in the Pentecontaetia

The following is an example of how Thucydides himself makes use of a future
indicative active verb in the Pentecontaetia.

οἱ ᾿Αθηναῖοι [...] |  **πέμψουσιν** |  πρέσβεις [...]  
---|---|---  
The Athenians [...]  |  **will send** |  ambassadors [...]  
(Nominative)  |  **(Verb)**   |  (Object)  
-- _The History of the Peloponnesian War_,
[1.90.3](/reader/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0003.tlg001.perseus-grc1:1.90.3)

[Keep Reading »](/reader/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0003.tlg001.perseus-grc1:1.90.3)

### πέμπω, _I send_

Future Active Indicative -- πέμψω, _I will send_

Person | Singular | Plural  
---|---|---  
1st | πέμψ**ω** | πέμψ**ομεν**  
2nd | πέμψ**εις** | πέμψ**ετε**  
3rd | πέμψ**ει** | πέμψ**ουσι(ν)**

fields.content:
![](/static/images/new_thuc.png) ![](/static/images/glasses.svg)

> _My future without you would be less vivid._ Thucydides _(ca 460 - 395 BC)_

# Future Indicative Active

* * *

Now that you are familiar with the present indicative active, you're ready to
lean the **future indicative active**!

* * *

## In this Section

New Skills New Vocab Rising Power of the Athenians!

  1. Identify future indicative active verbs.
  2. Conjugate future indicative active verbs.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### Thucydides

![](/static/images/thuc.png)

I am the only historian who has described the growth of Athenian power
accurately!

## ...previously in the Pentecontaetia

The Athenians formed an anti-Persian alliance.

## Now in the Pentecontaetia...

The power of the Athenians grows exponentially through their military and
political actions against the barbarians, against their own allies in revolt
and against the Peloponnesians. Athens' new alliance attacks locations, such
as Eion, Scyros, Carystus and Naxos, whose citizens initiate a revolt against
the confederacy.

οἱ Ἀθηναῖοι, the Athenians, grow more and more unpopular as they demand
monetary and military contributions from the allies. For this, οἱ ξύμμαχοι,
the allies, have themselves to blame; wishing to get off service, they had
decided to pay their share in money instead of in ships. Thus the Athenian
navy is growing richer than ever before.

(Summary of Thuc. 1.97-98-99)

Now that you've got some context, let's look at the Future Indicative Active
verbs!  
  
**Click the arrow to start learning!**

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### πέμπω, _I send_

Future Active Indicative -- πέμψω, _I will send_

Person | Singular | Plural  
---|---|---  
1st | πέμψ**ω** | πέμψ**ομεν**  
2nd | πέμψ**εις** | πέμψ**ετε**  
3rd | πέμψ**ει** | πέμψ**ουσι(ν)**  
  
## Future Indicative Active for Stop Verbs

The future stem of many verbs simply ends in σ, as you just learned.

But sometimes, when adding the σ to the end, it **combines with the final
letter of the present stem to form another letter**. Take a look at the three
categories below:

  

#### κ or γ or χ \+ σ **ξ**

* * *

For example:  

#### λέ**γ**ω, _I say_

#### λέ**ξ**ω, _I will say_

####

#### π or β or φ \+ σ **ψ**

* * *

For example:  

#### πέμ**π**ω, _I send_

#### πέμ**ψ**ω, _I will send_

####

#### τ or δ or θ \+ σ **σ**

* * *

For example:  

#### πεί**θ**ω, _I persuade_

#### πεί**σ**ω, _I will persuade_

####

fields.content:
##### ὁ ἡ τό, The

Case | Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | ὁ | ἡ | τό  
Gen. | τοῦ | τῆς | τοῦ  
Dat. | τῷ | τῇ | τῷ  
Acc. | τόν | τήν | τό  
Voc. | - | - | -  
**Plural**  
Nom. | οἱ | αἱ | τά  
Gen. | τῶν | τῶν | τῶν  
Dat. | τοῖς | ταῖς | τοῖς  
Acc. | τούς | τάς | τά  
Voc. | - | - | -  
  
#### The Nominative Case

##### Nominatives in the Pentecontaetia

Essentially every sentence in Greek contains a word in the nominative case.
Take a look at the very beginning of Thucydides' _Pentacontaetia_!

**οἱ** γὰρ **Ἀθηναῖοι** |  τρόπῳ τοιῷδε |  ἦλθον...  
---|---|---  
So **the Athenians**,  |  in this way,  |  came...  
**(Subject)** |    |  (Verb)   
-- _The History of the Peloponnesian War_, 1.89.1

Keep Reading »

![](/static/images/thuc.png)

Now that's an ominous start to any story, if I do say so myself...which I did.

Now that you have learned the **nominative**, test yourself!  
  
Click the arrow to try recognizing the dative in English and Greek sentences!

##### ὁ ἡ τό, The

Case | Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | ὁ | ἡ | τό  
Gen. | τοῦ | τῆς | τοῦ  
Dat. | τῷ | τῇ | τῷ  
Acc. | τόν | τήν | τό  
Voc. | - | - | -  
**Plural**  
Nom. | οἱ | αἱ | τά  
Gen. | τῶν | τῶν | τῶν  
Dat. | τοῖς | ταῖς | τοῖς  
Acc. | τούς | τάς | τά  
Voc. | - | - | -  
  
#### The Genitive Case

##### Genitive of Comparison

In these sentences, the genitive expresses **comparison**. When ἤ (than) is
absent, the **object of comparison** (i.e. anything after 'than' in English)
is in the genitive.

ὁ Θουκυδίδης |  ἐστὶ |  σώφρων |  **τοῦ παιδός**.  
---|---|---|---  
Thucydides  |  is  |  wiser  |  **than the boy**.  
(Nominative)  |  (Verb)  |  |  **(Genitive)**  
  
##### Genitive following Prepositions

In these sentences, the genitive follows **prepositions** for a variety of
purposes. Here is the example of the preposition **ἐκ** meaning **out
of/from**.

ἡ κόρη |  ἐκβαίνει |  **ἐκ τῆς οἰκίας.**  
---|---|---  
The girl  |  walks out  |  **of the house**  
(Nominative)  |  (Verb)  |  **(Genitive)**

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
##### ὁ ἡ τό, The

Case | Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | ὁ | ἡ | τό  
Gen. | τοῦ | τῆς | τοῦ  
Dat. | τῷ | τῇ | τῷ  
Acc. | τόν | τήν | τό  
Voc. | - | - | -  
**Plural**  
Nom. | οἱ | αἱ | τά  
Gen. | τῶν | τῶν | τῶν  
Dat. | τοῖς | ταῖς | τοῖς  
Acc. | τούς | τάς | τά  
Voc. | - | - | -  
  
#### The Genitive Case

##### Partitive Genitive

In these sentences, the genitive indicates the **part of something**.

ἡ συντυχία  |  **τῆς ἱστορίας** |  ἐστὶ |  βραχεῖα.  
---|---|---|---  
The event  |  **of (out of) the narrative** |  is  |  short.  
(Nominative)  |  **(Genitive)** |  (Verb)  |  
  
##### Genitive of Separation

In these sentences, the genitive indicates the **separation or lack of
something**.

ἡ κόρη |  ἀφίσταται |  **τῶν κινδύνων.**  
---|---|---  
The girl  |  stays away  |  **from the dangers**  
(Nominative)  |  (Verb)  |  **(Genitive)**  
  
##### Genitive with verbs of Desire

In these sentences, the genitive follows **verbs of desire**.

ὁ Θουκυδίδης |  ἐπιθυμέι |  **τῆς ἡσυχίας.**  
---|---|---  
Thucydides  |  desires  |  **rest.**  
(Nominative)  |  (Verb)  |  **(Genitive)**

fields.content:
##### ὁ ἡ τό, The

Case | Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | ὁ | ἡ | τό  
Gen. | τοῦ | τῆς | τοῦ  
Dat. | τῷ | τῇ | τῷ  
Acc. | τόν | τήν | τό  
Voc. | - | - | -  
**Plural**  
Nom. | οἱ | αἱ | τά  
Gen. | τῶν | τῶν | τῶν  
Dat. | τοῖς | ταῖς | τοῖς  
Acc. | τούς | τάς | τά  
Voc. | - | - | -  
  
#### The Nominative Case

##### What's in a name?

The word "nominative" originally comes from the Greek word ὄνομα, meaning
"name". Thus, the nominative case is used to indicate the **subject of a
sentence** or the **complement of the verb**.

* * *

##### Keep an eye out!

Take a look at the table to your left. We'll be focusing mostly on words that
fit into this pattern, or **declension**.

fields.content:
##### ὁ ἡ τό, The

Case | Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | ὁ | ἡ | τό  
Gen. | τοῦ | τῆς | τοῦ  
Dat. | τῷ | τῇ | τῷ  
Acc. | τόν | τήν | τό  
Voc. | - | - | -  
**Plural**  
Nom. | οἱ | αἱ | τά  
Gen. | τῶν | τῶν | τῶν  
Dat. | τοῖς | ταῖς | τοῖς  
Acc. | τούς | τάς | τά  
Voc. | - | - | -  
  
#### The Dative Case

##### Dative meaning **in**

In these sentences, the dative expresses **metaphorical or physical
location**. Thucydides often uses the dative in this way. When indicating a
physical location, the dative is often preceeded by the preposition **ἐν**.

ὁ ἀνήρ |  ἐστὶ |  νέος |  **ἡλικίᾳ**.  
---|---|---|---  
The man  |  is  |  young  |  **in age**.  
(Nominative)  |  (Verb)  |  (Complement)  |  **(Dative)**  
  
##### Dative meaning **with** or **by**

In these sentences, the dative expresses **means or instrument**. Thucydides
often uses the dative in this way.

ἡ κόρη |  βάλλει |  τόν ἄνδρα |  **λίθοις**  
---|---|---|---  
The girl  |  hits  |  the man  |  **with stones**.  
(Nominative)  |  (Verb)  |  **(Accusative)** |  **(Dative)**

fields.content:
##### ὁ ἡ τό, The

Case | Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---

Gen. | τοῦ | τῆς | τοῦ  
Dat. | τῷ | τῇ | τῷ  
Acc. | τόν | τήν | τό

**Plural**

Gen. | τῶν | τῶν | τῶν

Acc. | τούς | τάς | τά  
Voc. | - | - | -  
  
#### The Dative Case

##### Datives in the Pentecontaetia

In this section right at the beginning of the Pentecontaetia, Thucydides talks
about king Leotychides' victory at Mycale in 479BC, when he gave the Persians
the final blow.

Λεωτυχίδης |  **ἡγεῖτο** |  τῶν Ἑλλήνων |  ἐν Μυκάλῃ...  
---|---|---|---  
Leotychides  |  led  |  the Greeks  |  at Mycale...  
(Nominative)  |  (Verb - ἡγέομαι takes an object in the genitive)  |
(Genitive)  |  **(Dative)**  
-- _The History of the Peloponnesian War_, 1.89.2

Keep Reading »

![](/static/images/thuc.png)

King ὁ Λεωτυχίδης is badass!

##### Almost there!

Now that you have learned the **dative**, test yourself!  
  
Click the arrow to try recognizing the dative in English and Greek sentences!

fields.content:
![](/static/images/new_thuc.png) ![](/static/images/glasses.svg)

> _Conjugate a noun? I decline._ Thucydides _(ca 460 - 395 BC)_

### How Cases Work

* * *

In "Introduction to Nouns" you learned that in Greek there are **5 main
cases**: nominative, accusative, genitive, dative and vocative. Understanding
cases is vital to help you translate a text.

* * *

#### In this Section

New Skills New Vocab Protagonists of the Peloponnesian War.

  1. Identify the cases.
  2. Know what the function of each word is in a sentence.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
##### ὁ ἡ τό, The

Case | Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | ὁ | ἡ | τό  
Gen. | τοῦ | τῆς | τοῦ  
Dat. | τῷ | τῇ | τῷ  
Acc. | τόν | τήν | τό  
Voc. | - | - | -  
**Plural**  
Nom. | οἱ | αἱ | τά  
Gen. | τῶν | τῶν | τῶν  
Dat. | τοῖς | ταῖς | τοῖς  
Acc. | τούς | τάς | τά  
Voc. | - | - | -  
  
#### The Genitive Case

##### Genitives in the Pentecontaetia

In this section right at the beginning of the Pentecontaetia, the Persians
have just suffered the final defeat by the Greeks, or _Hellenes_, led by the
Spartan king Leotychides.

Λεωτυχίδης μὲν ὁ βασιλεὺς |  **τῶν Λακεδαιμονίων** |  ἀπεχώρησεν |  ἐπ᾽ οἴκου  
---|---|---|---  
Leotychides, king  |  of the Spartans  |  set out  |  towards home...  
(Nominative)  |  **(Genitive)** |  (Verb)  |  
-- _The History of the Peloponnesian War_, 1.89.2

Keep Reading »

![](/static/images/thuc.png)

Finally ὁ Λεωτυχίδης ὁ βασιλεὺς has defeated the Persians! Can there be peace
now?

##### Almost there!

Now that you have learned the **genitive**, test yourself!  
  
Click on the arrow to try recognizing the genitive in English and Greek
sentences!

fields.content:
##### ὁ ἡ τό, The

Case | Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | ὁ | ἡ | τό  
Gen. | τοῦ | τῆς | τοῦ  
Dat. | τῷ | τῇ | τῷ  
Acc. | τόν | τήν | τό  
Voc. | - | - | -  
**Plural**  
Nom. | οἱ | αἱ | τά  
Gen. | τῶν | τῶν | τῶν  
Dat. | τοῖς | ταῖς | τοῖς  
Acc. | τούς | τάς | τά  
Voc. | - | - | -  
  
#### The Genitive Case

In most cases the meaning of the genitive can be associated with the English
word **_of_**, so if you take the sentence _Thucydides wrote a narration of
events_, you will find "of events" in the genitive.

* * *

##### Useful tip!

The genitive is a very useful case. Very often the ending of the genitive will
help you determine the gender and number of irregular nouns that in the
nominative may confuse you. For example, we know the name "Thucydides" is
masculine, though the ending Θουκυδίδ**ης** may look feminine. The genitive
here, however, shows you that this noun is undoubtedly masculine:
Θουκυδίδ**ου**.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
##### ὁ ἡ τό, The

Case | Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | ὁ | ἡ | τό  
Gen. | τοῦ | τῆς | τοῦ  
Dat. | τῷ | τῇ | τῷ  
Acc. | τόν | τήν | τό  
Voc. | - | - | -  
**Plural**  
Nom. | οἱ | αἱ | τά  
Gen. | τῶν | τῶν | τῶν  
Dat. | τοῖς | ταῖς | τοῖς  
Acc. | τούς | τάς | τά  
Voc. | - | - | -  
  
#### The Nominative Case

##### Nominative as the Complement

The complement, which is also a noun or adjective in the nominative case,
**always follows the verb _to be_**. Spotting the verb first can help you
understand the function of the other words in the sentence!

**ἡ ἡμέρα** |  ἐστὶ |  **μακρά**.  
---|---|---  
**The day** |  is  |  **long**.   
**(Subject)** |  (Linking Verb)  |  **(Complement)**  
  
* * *

**ὁ Θουκυδίδης** |  ἐστὶ |  **συγγραφεύς**  
---|---|---  
**Thucydides** |  is  |  **a historian**.   
**(Subject)** |  (Linking Verb)  |  **(Complement)**  
  
* * *

**Σικελία** |  ἐστὶ |  **νῆσος**  
---|---|---  
**Sicily** |  is  |  **an island**.   
**(Subject)** |  (Linking Verb)  |  **(Complement)**  
  
#####  Useful tip!

The Greek word order might surprise you. You will find that the word order
doesn't follow particular conventions and the verb may often be at the end of
a sentence!

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
![](/static/images/map_war_small.png)

#### Quick Recap!

* * *

So, you've learned that Thucydides is the author of the _History of the
Peloponnesian War_, the story of the great ὁ πόλεμος, the war, fought between
the Peloponnesian League, led by οἱ Λακεδαιμόνιοι, the Spartans, and the
Delian League, led by οἱ ᾿Αθηναῖοι, the Athenians. As you go through the
lessons you will become particularly familiar with one part of Thucydides'
great historical account -- a section of the first book called ἡ
πεντηκονταετία, **The Pentecontaetia**.

  
  

#### Can you guess what Pentecontaetia means?

* * *

The word is a combination of πεντήκοντα meaning fifty and ετία meaning age.
The fifty year age marks the period between the defeat of the second Persian
invasion of Greece in 479 BC and the beginning of the Peloponnesian war in 433
BC, when **Athens was gradually becoming the most powerful state in the Greek
world**. Athens was in fact building its empire and exercised control over the
allies with its fierce ἡ στρατιά, its army, named the Delian League.

![](/static/images/thuc.png)

Now that you've got some context, let's start out with the basics of cases in
Greek. **Click the arrow to start learning!**

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## The Accusative Case

### Accusative for Direct Objects

The accusative case is used to indicate the **direct object of a verb**. A
direct object is the thing being acted upon by the subject.

ὁ Θουκυδίδης |  ἐξηγέται |  **τόν πόλεμον**.  
---|---|---  
Thucydides  |  describes  |  **the war**.  
(Subject)  |  (Verb)  |  **(Direct Object)**  
ἡ πόλις |  ἔχει |  **στρατίαν**.  
---|---|---  
The city  |  has  |  **an army**.  
(Subject)  |  (Verb)  |  **(Direct Object)**  
  
##### Don't forget!

While there is a Greek transaltion for the definite article "the", there is no
translation for the indefinite article "a" or "an". In this case, you can just
skip the Greek article and translate the noun directly.

##### ὁ ἡ τό, The

Case | Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | ὁ | ἡ | τό  
Gen. | τοῦ | τῆς | τοῦ  
Dat. | τῷ | τῇ | τῷ  
Acc. | τόν | τήν | τό  
Voc. | - | - | -  
**Plural**  
Nom. | οἱ | αἱ | τά  
Gen. | τῶν | τῶν | τῶν  
Dat. | τοῖς | ταῖς | τοῖς  
Acc. | τούς | τάς | τά  
Voc. | - | - | -

#### The Dative Case

##### Datives in the Pentecontaetia

In this section right at the beginning of the Pentecontaetia, Thucydides talks
about king Leotychides' victory at Mycale in 479BC, when he gave the Persians
the final blow.

Λεωτυχίδης |  **ἡγεῖτο** |  τῶν Ἑλλήνων |  ἐν Μυκάλῃ...  
---|---|---|---  
Leotychides  |  led  |  the Greeks  |  at Mycale...  
(Nominative)  |  (Verb - ἡγέομαι takes an object in the genitive)  |
(Genitive)  |  **(Dative)**

Keep Reading »

![](/static/images/thuc.png)

King ὁ Λεωτυχίδης is badass!

Click on the arrow to try recognizing the dative in English and Greek

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
#### The Dative Case

The word "dative" derives from the Latin word _dare_, meaning to "give". In
most cases its meaning can be associated with the English words **to** and
**for**. It goes naturally with verbs of giving, so if you take the sentence
_Thucydides gave a story to the audience_, you will find "to the audience" in
the dative.

These verbs are generally followed by a direct object in the accusative and an
_indirect object in the dative_. Take a look at the example below!

ὁ ἀνήρ |  δίδωσι |  δῶρον |  **τῇ κόρῃ**.  
---|---|---|---  
The man  |  gives  |  a rose  |  **to the girl**.  
(Nominative)  |  (Verb)  |  (Accusative)  |  **(Dative)**  
  
##### ὁ ἡ τό, The

Case | Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | ὁ | ἡ | τό  
Gen. | τοῦ | τῆς | τοῦ  
Dat. | τῷ | τῇ | τῷ  
Acc. | τόν | τήν | τό  
Voc. | - | - | -  
**Plural**  
Nom. | οἱ | αἱ | τά  
Gen. | τῶν | τῶν | τῶν  
Dat. | τοῖς | ταῖς | τοῖς  
Acc. | τούς | τάς | τά  
Voc. | - | - | -

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
##### ὁ ἡ τό, The

Case | Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | ὁ | ἡ | τό  
Gen. | τοῦ | τῆς | τοῦ  
Dat. | τῷ | τῇ | τῷ  
Acc. | τόν | τήν | τό  
Voc. | - | - | -  
**Plural**  
Nom. | οἱ | αἱ | τά  
Gen. | τῶν | τῶν | τῶν  
Dat. | τοῖς | ταῖς | τοῖς  
Acc. | τούς | τάς | τά  
Voc. | - | - | -  
  
#### The Vocative Case

The vocative is the case by which one addresses or calls out to someone. It is
generally very similar in form to the nominative. Notice there is no definite
article for it in the table. That is because **there is no definite article
for the vocative**, though often it is preceeded by the interjection ὦ.

**ὦ Ζεῦ,** |  ὁ βίος |  ἐστὶ |  χαλεπὸς.  
---|---|---|---  
**O Zeus,** |  life  |  is  |  difficult.   
**(Vocative)** |  (Nominative)  |  (Verb)  |  (Complement)   
  
**Θουκυδίδες,** |  ἀκούεις;  
---|---  
**Thucydides,** |  do you hear?   
(Vocative)  |  (Verb)

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
## The Nominative Case

### Nominative as the Subject

In these sentences, the subject of the sentence is marked by the nominative
case.

**ὁ Θουκυδίδης** |  ἐξηγέται |  τόν πόλεμον.  
---|---|---  
**Thucydides** |  describes  |  the war.   
**(Subject)** |  (Verb)  |  (Object)   
  
* * *

**ἡ ἡμέρα** |  φέρει |  τήν ἡσυχίαν  
---|---|---  
**The day** |  brings  |  rest.   
**(Subject)** |  (Verb)  |  (Object)   
  
#####  Useful tip!

You can always rely on the definite article, such as ὁ or ἡ in these examples,
to indicate the nominative case.

##### ὁ ἡ τό, The

Case | Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | ὁ | ἡ | τό  
Gen. | τοῦ | τῆς | τοῦ  
Dat. | τῷ | τῇ | τῷ  
Acc. | τόν | τήν | τό  
Voc. | - | - | -  
**Plural**  
Nom. | οἱ | αἱ | τά  
Gen. | τῶν | τῶν | τῶν  
Dat. | τοῖς | ταῖς | τοῖς  
Acc. | τούς | τάς | τά  
Voc. | - | - | -

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
##### ὁ ἡ τό, The

Case | Masc. | Fem. | Neut.  
---|---|---|---  
**Singular**  
Nom. | ὁ | ἡ | τό  
Gen. | τοῦ | τῆς | τοῦ  
Dat. | τῷ | τῇ | τῷ  
Acc. | τόν | τήν | τό  
Voc. | - | - | -  
**Plural**  
Nom. | οἱ | αἱ | τά  
Gen. | τῶν | τῶν | τῶν  
Dat. | τοῖς | ταῖς | τοῖς  
Acc. | τούς | τάς | τά  
Voc. | - | - | -  
  
#### The Accusative Case

##### Accusative in the Pentecontaetia!

In this section, Thucydides is describing the Athenians taking over the city
of Sestus. When they were sure that the barbarians were gone for good, the
soldiers went back for their families.

Ἀθηναίων δὲ τὸ κοινόν [...] |  ὅθεν ὑπεξέθεντο |  **παῖδας** καὶ **γυναῖκας**.  
---|---|---  
The people of Athens  |  brought over  |  **children** and **women**.  
(Subject)  |  (Verb)  |  **(Direct Objects)**  
-- _The History of the Peloponnesian War_, 1.89.3

Keep Reading »

Now that you have learnt the **accusative**, test yourself by clicking on the
arrow and completing the exercises!

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
##### Pluperfect Indicative Active, _To have_

Person | Subject | Verb  
---|---|---  
**Singular**  
1st | I | had had  
2nd | You | had had  
3rd | He/She/It | had had | **Plural**  
1st | We | had had  
2nd | You | had had  
3rd | They | had had  
  
#### Pluperfect Indicative Active

As you remember from "Introduction to Verbs":

  * The**pluperfect tense**Describes an action in the past time with completed aspect (i.e. fixed moment in time that has come to an end).
  * The**indicative mood**is used for factual statements and questions.
  * The**active voice**means the subject of the verb is performing the action.

Here are some examples of the aorist in English: _**I had seen** it in the
past._

* * *

##### Keep an eye out!

Remember that unlike English verbs, the subject of the Greek verb is implied
by the verb's ending. Therefore, it is not necessary for it to be accompanied
by the personal pronouns _I, You, He/She/It, We, You, They_.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
![](/static/images/new_thuc.png) ![](/static/images/glasses.svg)

> _Don't be tense... You'll be pluperfect!_ Thucydides _(ca 460 - 395 BC)_

# Pluperfect Indicative Active

* * *

Now that you are familiar with the perfect, it's a good tim to learn about the
**pluperfect indicative active**!

* * *

## In this Section

New Skills New Vocab \--.

  1. Identify pluperfect indicative active verbs.
  2. Conjugate pluperfect indicative active verbs.

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
###

![](/static/images/map_war_small.png)

## ...previously in the Pentecontaetia

General Cimon died in Cyprus after the Athenians conquer Citium.

## Now in the Pentecontaetia...

The Boeotians regain independence from Athens after a battle at Coronea, in
which many Athenians are killed and taken captive.

Soon after Euboea and Megara also revolt against the Athenians. Though
managing to squash the Euboeian revolt, Pericles struggles to calm Megara.

The Peloponnesian army also invades Attica, but soon turns back!

(Summary of Thuc. 1.113-114)

Now that you've got some context, let's look at the pluperfect!  
  
**Click the arrow to start learning!**

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### λύω, _I untie_

Pluperfect Indicative Active -- ἐλελύκειν, _I had untied_

Person | Singular | Plural  
---|---|---  
1st | **ἐ**λελύκ**ειν** | **ἐ**λελύκ**ειμεν**  
2nd | **ἐ**ἐλελύκ**εις** | **ἐ**ἐλελύκ**ειτε**  
3rd | **ἐ**ἐλελύκ**ει** | **ἐ**ἐλελύκ**εισα(ν)**  
  
#### Pluperfect Indicative Active

To form the pluperfect indicative active:

  1. **Take the fourth principle part** (the one for the perfect tense).   
e.g. λέλυκα

  2. **Remove the ending** (-α) to get the the perfect stem.   
e.g. λέλυκ-

**Add the augment ἐ**.   
e.g. ἐλέλυκ-

  3. **Add the the endings you see in the table.**   
e.g. ἐλελύκειν, meaning _I had untied_.

* * *

The Parts of an Pluperfect Tense Verb

ἐ

* * *

|  λε

* * *

|  λύ

* * *

|  κ

* * *

|  ειν

* * *  
  
---|---|---|---|---  
**Augment**  
**

* * *

|  **Reduplication**  
**

* * *

|  **Stem**  
**

* * *

|  **Suffix**  

* * *

|  **Ending**

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
#### Aorist Indicative Active

The following is a list of verbs with their corresponding aorists that can be
often found in Ancient Greek texts. Notice how all of these have **second**
aorists. Try learning them!

1st: Present | 2nd: Future | 3rd: Aorist  
---|---|---  
ἄγω (I lead) | ἄξω (I will lead) | **ἤγαγον** (I led)  
βάλλω (I throw) | βαλῶ (I will throw) | **ἔβαλον** (I threw)  
πείθω (I persuade) | πείσω (I will persuade) | **ἔπεισα** (I persuaded)  
τέμνω (I cut) | τεμῶ (I will cut) | **ἔτεμον** (I cut)

fields.title: UPDATE ME!
fields.content:
### φαίνω, _I show_

Aorist Indicative Active -- ἔφηνα, _I showed_

Person | Singular | Plural  
---|---|---  
1st | **ἔ**φην**α** | **ἐ**φήν**αμεν**  
2nd | **ἔ**φήν**ας** | **ἐ**φήν**ατε**  
3rd | **ἔ**φην**ε(ν)** | **ἔ**φην**αν**  
  
#### Aorist Indicative Active

The **asigmatic** aorist behaves in a similar way to the sigmatic aorist.
You'll notice, however, that in this case it is not as easy to separate the
stem. Often with the aorist, it is just a case of memorizing the **third
principle part** of some common words.

For example, in the case of φαίνω, _to show_, the aorist indicative active is
ἔφηνα. You'll see how here there is **no sigma**, but the endings remain **the
same as the sigmatic aorist**.

* * *

The Parts of an Aorist Tense Verb

ἔ

* * *

|  φην

* * *

|  α

* * *  
  
---|---|---  
**Augment**  
**

* * *

|  **Asigmatic Stem**  
**

* * *

|  **Ending**  

* * *

fields.title: Aorist Indicative Active for Stop Verbs
fields.content:
### πέμπω, _I send_

Aorist Active Indicative -- ἔπεμψα, _I sent_

Person | Singular | Plural  
---|---|---  
1st | **ἔ**πεμψ**α** | **ἐ**πέμψ**αμεν**  
2nd | **ἔ**πεμψ**ας** | **ἐ**πέμψ**ατε**  
3rd | **ἔ**πεμψ**ε(ν)** | **ἔ**πεμψ**ουσι(ν)**  
  
#### Aorist Indicative Active for Stop Verbs

The aorist stem of many verbs simply ends in σ, as you just learned.

But sometimes, when adding the σ to the end, it **combines with the final
letter of the present stem to form another letter**. Take a look at the three
categories below:

  

#### κ or γ or χ \+ σ **ξ**

* * *

For example:  

#### λέ**γ**ω, _I say_

#### ἔλε**ξ**α, _I said_

####

#### π or β or φ \+ σ **ψ**

* * *

For example:  

#### πέμ**π**ω, _I send_

#### ἔπεμ**ψ**α, _I sent_

####

#### τ or δ or θ \+ σ **σ**

* * *

For example:  

#### πεί**θ**ω, _I persuade_

#### ἔπει**σ**α, _I persuaded_

####

fields.title: Introduction to the Aorist
fields.content:
![](/static/images/new_thuc.png) ![](/static/images/glasses.svg)

> _When in doubt, aorist._ Thucydides _(ca 460 - 395 BC)_

# Aorist Indicative Active

* * *

Now that you are familiar with third declension nouns with consonant stems,
this is a good time to carry on learning the verbs. Here you will learn about
the **aorist indicative active**!

* * *

## In this Section

New Skills New Vocab New Athenian battles and victories

  1. Identify aorist indicative active verbs.
  2. Conjugate aorist indicative active verbs.

fields.title: The Second (Asigmatic) Aorist
fields.content:
### λείπω, _I leave_

Aorist Indicative Active -- ἔλιπον, _I left_

Person | Singular | Plural  
---|---|---  
1st | **ἔ**λιπ**ον** | **ἐ**λίπ**ομεν**  
2nd | **ἔ**λιπ**ες** | **ἐ**λίπ**ετε**  
3rd | **ἔ**λιπ**ε(ν)** | **ἔ**λιπ**ον**  
  
#### Aorist Indicative Active: Second Aorist

In the **third principle part** of the verbs you have seen so far, the ending
for the first person singular has always been -α. This is becasue the verbs
you have seen so far have **first aorists**. There are, however, some verbs
with **second aorists**. For these **the endings change**, despite the meaning
remaining the same as first aorists.

For example, in the case of λείπω, _to leave_, the aorist indicative active is
ἔλιπον. **The endings of the second aorist active resemble those of the
imperfect.**

* * *

The Parts of an Aorist Tense Verb

ἔ

* * *

|  λιπ

* * *

|  ον

* * *  
  
---|---|---  
**Augment**  
**

* * *

|  **Stem**  
**

* * *

|  **Ending**  

* * *

fields.title: The First (Sigmatic) Aorist
fields.content:
### λύω, _I untie_

Aorist Indicative Active -- ἔλυσα, _I untied_

Person | Singular | Plural  
---|---|---  
1st | **ἔ**λυσ**α** | **ἐ**λύσ**αμεν**  
2nd | **ἔ**λυσ**ας** | **ἐ**λύσ**ατε**  
3rd | **ἔ**λυσ**ε(ν)** | **ἔ**λυσ**αν**  
  
#### Aorist Indicative Active

The aorist can have many different endings. The general rule, however, is that
the aorist can be either **sigmatic** (meaning with an added σ) or
**asigmatic** (without σ).

To form the sigmatic aorist indicative active:

  1. **Take the present tense form**, also known as the first "principle part".   
e.g. λύω

  2. **Remove the ending** (-ω) to get the the present stem.   
e.g. λύ-

**Add the augment ἐ** (just like you did for the imperfect). 
  3. **Add a σ** to get the sigmatic aorist stem.   
e.g. ἔλυσ-

  4. **Add the endings** from the table to indicate the person and number.   
e.g. ἐλύσαμεν, _We untied_

The aorist then becomes the **third principle part** of a verb.

* * *

The Parts of an Aorist Tense Verb

ἔ

* * *

|  λυ

* * *

|  σ

* * *

|  α

* * *  
  
---|---|---|---  
**Augment**  
**

* * *

|  **Stem**  
**

* * *

|  ****σ****  

* * *

|  **Ending**  

* * *

fields.title: History - Thuc. 1.105-106
fields.content:
###

![](/static/images/map_war_small.png)

## ...previously in the Pentecontaetia

The Athenians established themselves as masters of the river Nile.

## Now in the Pentecontaetia...

War breaks out between Athens and the island opposite, Aegina. The Athenians
win a great sea battle against the island and take seventy of Aegina's ships.
Desirous to help the Aeginetans, the Peloponnesians send 300 hoplites to their
aid.

Meanwhile, οἱ Κορίνθιοι, the Corithians march down to attack Athens, believing
most of their army employed in Aegina. However, after a drawn battle, the
Athenians defeat the Corinthians, who retreat home.

(Summary of Thuc. 1.105-106)

Now that you've got some context, let's look at the aorist!  
  
**Click the arrow to start learning!**

fields.title: The Aorist Indicative Active in English
fields.content:
##### Aorist Indicative Active, _To have_

Person | Subject | Verb  
---|---|---  
**Singular**  
1st | I | had  
2nd | You | had  
3rd | He/She/It | had | **Plural**  
1st | We | had  
2nd | You | had  
3rd | They | had  
  
#### Aorist Indicative Active

As you remember from "Introduction to Verbs":

  * The**aorist tense**describes an action in the past time with simple aspect (i.e. fixed moment in time).
  * The**indicative mood**is used for factual statements and questions.
  * The**active voice**means the subject of the verb is performing the action.

Here are some examples of the aorist in English: _I **heard** a noise.
Suddenly darkness **fell**._

* * *

##### Keep an eye out!

Remember that unlike English verbs, the subject of the Greek verb is implied
by the verb's ending. Therefore, it is not necessary for it to be accompanied
by the personal pronouns _I, You, He/She/It, We, You, They_.

fields.content:
#### Aorist Indicative Active

The following is a list of verbs with their corresponding aorists that can be
often found in Ancient Greek texts. Notice how all of these have **asigmatic**
aorists.

Present | Aorist | Note  
---|---|---  
ἀγγέλλω (I announce) | **ἤγγειλα | The augment has changed from ε to η
following a merge of α \+ ε  
κρίνω (I judge) | **ἔκρινα |  
περαίνω (I finish) | **ἐπέρανα |

fields.title: The Perfect Indicative Active Paradigm
fields.content:
### λύω, _I untie_

Perfect Indicative Active -- λέλυκα, _I have untied_

Person | Singular | Plural  
---|---|---  
1st | **λέ**λυ**κα** | **λε**λύ**καμεν**  
2nd | **λέ**λυ**κας** | **λε**λύ**κατε**  
3rd | **λέ**λυ**κε** | **λε**λύ**κασι(ν)**  
  
#### Perfect Indicative Active

To form the perfect indicative active:

  1. **Take the present tense form**, also known as the first "principle part".   
e.g. λύω

  2. **Remove the ending** (-ω) to get the the present stem.   
e.g. λύ-

**Add the augment ε** (just like you did for the imperfect and aorist). 
  3. **Add the first letter of the stem** in front of the augment.   
e.g. λέλυ-

  4. **Add the suffix -κ**.   
e.g. λέλυκ-.

  5. **Add the the endings of the present indicative active**, except for the third person singular, where the ending can be either -ε or -ο, depending on the verb.   
e.g. λέλυκα, meaning _I have untied_.

The perfect then becomes the **fourth principle part** of a verb.

* * *

The Parts of an Perfect Tense Verb

λέ

* * *

|  λυ

* * *

|  κ

* * *

|  α

* * *  
  
---|---|---|---  
**Reduplication**  
**

* * *

|  **Stem**  
**

* * *

|  **Suffix**  

* * *

|  **Ending**  

* * *

fields.title: The Perfect Indicative Active in English
fields.content:
##### Perfect Indicative Active, _To have_

Person | Subject | Verb  
---|---|---  
**Singular**  
1st | I | have had  
2nd | You | have had  
3rd | He/She/It | has had | **Plural**  
1st | We | have had  
2nd | You | have had  
3rd | They | have had  
  
#### Perfect Indicative Active

As you remember from "Introduction to Verbs":

  * The**perfect tense**Describes an action in the present time with completed aspect (i.e. fixed moment in time that has come to an end).
  * The**indicative mood**is used for factual statements and questions.
  * The**active voice**means the subject of the verb is performing the action.

Here are some examples of the aorist in English: _I **have had** a long life.
I **have lived**._

* * *

##### Keep an eye out!

Remember that unlike English verbs, the subject of the Greek verb is implied
by the verb's ending. Therefore, it is not necessary for it to be accompanied
by the personal pronouns _I, You, He/She/It, We, You, They_.

fields.title: History - Thuc. 1.112
fields.content:
###

![](/static/images/map.jpg)

## ...previously in the Pentecontaetia

The Athenians failed to conquer Thessaly and Acarnia, but were successful in
Sicyon.

## Now in the Pentecontaetia...

After three years of battling, the Athenians and the Peloponnesians make a
truce. The Athenians, now free from the Hellenic war, decide to send 200
vessels towars Cyprus, 60 of which headed to Egypt. The ships are lead by
Κίμων, Cimon, who lays siege at Citium. Cimon dies shortly after, due to lack
of provisions and the whole army leaves Citium and reunites with the vessels
who had gone to Egypt. During their return they are attacked by Phoenicians,
Cyprians and Cilicians, but they manage to defeat them!

In the meantime, the Spartans become masters of Delphi, but are soon sent away
by the Athenians!

(Summary of Thuc. 1.112)

Now that you've got some context, let's look at the perfect!
